business.start.para: The President (Senator the Hon. P. J. Lynch) took the chair at 11 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: - Has the attention of. the Leader of the Senate been drawn to the following press report in this morning's Canberra Times ? -

quote.para: COUNTRY PARTY.
Prime Minister Nails Lie.
Melbourne, Tuesday.

The Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons) said to-day that his attention had been called to a statement that the Country party in December, 1931, had refused to enter the Commonwealth Government because of its tariff policy, or some alteration in the tariff policy of the leaders of the United Australia party. This statement, said Mr. Lyons, has only recently been made. The claim was never suggested at the time. The persistence in the mis-statement fortunately does not make it true.

question.para: If so, has he any statement to make to the Senate onthe matter?

talk.start.para: - I have nothing to add to the statement made by the Prime Minister (Mr. Lyons).

- Will the Lyons Government instruct Mr. Bruce, M.H.R., the Resident Minister in London, to inform the international delegates to the World Economic Conference now sitting in London that the causes of unemployment and the general depression in Australia are: -

item.para: Private ownership of production and production for profit, and lack of effective purchasing power in the hands of Australian workers.

Labour-saving devices, mechanical and organizational, by which a proportion of the population is enabled to supply the needs of the whole population, and the fact that, instead of the labour of all., being reduced, a proportion of the population works as long us, or lunger than, before, while the rest works little or no time at all.
Violent fluctuations in trade, due to the anarchy of competitive production with its booms and slumps.
Changes in production, e.g., petrol and electricity taking the place of steam-power from coal.
The tendency for manufacture to gravitate to the sources of raw material, power and cheap labour!

talk.start.para: - Apparently, the honorable senator has forgotten that he may not express opinions when asking questions. I cannot allow him to continue in that strain.
- Surely the existence of 70,000,000 persons unemployed in the world, and of 500,000 slaves looking for jobs in Australia is a matter of importance!
- There is a proper time for the honorable senator to express his opinions. He may not do so now.
- The answer to the honorable senator's question is No.
- Has the Minister in charge of development any statement to make in regard to the latest reports from Paris regarding the obtaining of oil from shale, coal lignites, and brown coal?

- I informed the honorable senator some days ago that Mr.Rogers, the Australian fuel expert, who is at present overseas, had been instructed to get into touch with the Parisian chemist whose investigations have been given prominence, and the results of which were reported to the Government a few days ago by the High Commissioner's Office in London. Yesterday, I released to the press a statement in connexion with this subject; but it had relation only to the earlier tests which took place before those referred to in the recent cabled advice. This matter is receiving the closest attention of the Government.

- I now ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether it would not have been a courteous act on the part of the Minister to make a statement in the Senate as well as to supply information to the press ?
- The Minister has made a statement to the Senate this morning.
- But not the statement which was supplied to the press.
asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that, owing to the alterations in the Pensions Act and regulations made last year, greatly increased responsibility and work have been imposed upon all Deputy Pensions Commissioners and their principal officers throughout the Commonwealth?
Will the Minister recommend to the appropriate authority the reclassifying of these positions with a view to increasing the salary and status thereof?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable senator's questions are as follow:-

item.para: Yes.
This matter is the subject of a report preparedby the Commissioner of Pensions, which will be considered by the Minister on his return to Canberra.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Customs, upon notice -

item.para: The number of Tariff Board recommendations in customs tariff items that were received by the Minister from November, 1931, up to thelatest date available?
How many had minority reports attached?
What were the subjects of the minority reports, if any, and the names of the members who signed them?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable senator's questions are as follow:-

item.para: One hundred and seven.
None.
See reply to No. 2.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Will he state the reason why the Broadcasting Commission on Friday last reduced the Sydney orchestra from 30 to 24 members?
Is it a fact that the commission's share of the revenue last year from broadcasting: licences was over £251,000?
Is not this revenue steadily increasing?
Have economies been effected by reducing the number of rehearsals, which also affects the salaries of musicians?
Is it a fact that the bulk of broadcasting programmes are provided by musicians?
Is it a fact that considerable unemployment has been existing in the ranks of musicians due to the advent of talkies, and that the Broadcasting Commission's operations have helped to relieve this?
Will the commission have to repay to the Commonwealth Government £17,000 by the end of June, money advanced by the Government?
If so, is this the reason for the dismissal of these musicians?
Will not the quality of the programmes supplied be seriously affected by this reduction in the size of the orchestra?
Will the Minister make representations to the commission not to spoil good music by cutting down the number of instrumentalists?

talk.start.para: - Inquiries are being made, and a reply will be furnished to the honorable senator as soon as possible.
asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Interior, upon notice -

quote.para: Has any progress been made in the negotiations in connexion with the proposed BourkeDar win railway ?

talk.start.para: The Minister for the Interior has supplied the following answer: - No

subdebate.1.para: Appointment of Machinists

talk.start.para: asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, upon notice-.

item.para: Will the Minister make inquiries as to why another examination for female machinists in the Federal Public Service, New South Wales, is to be held while there are still successful candidates from a previous examination not yet appointed, although these officers have been performing the duties of machinist for periods of not less than six months and as long as eighteen months and are at present performing such duties?

If it is a fact that certain officers who passed a traffic officers' examination held on the 26th September, 1927, and also officers who passed a senior mechanics' examination on 20th November, 1926, have had the period of their eligibility extended to the present time; will the same right be conceded to machinists who passed examination No. 1,764 held on the 18th October, 1930, or will a further period of six months to cover their eligibility for appointment be granted?
Are there at present any vacancies for machinists in New South Wales?
Are certain officers who have passed the necessary examination acting in vacant or uncreated positions?
If so, will the matter of their appointment be given immediate consideration in view of the fact that the date of their eligibility expires on the 23rd June, 1933?

talk.start.para: >The information is being obtained, and will be made available as soon as possible.

subdebate.1.para: Transfer to Canberra

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Has the attention of the Government been drawn to a statement made in the Melbourne Herald of the 2nd instant in which Mr. Cerutty, the Federal Auditor-General, describes as" irresponsible and untruthful gossip " the statement that he defied the Government when asked to transfer to Canberra?
Is it a fact, as stated by Mr. Cerutty, that he has never refused to go to Canberra?
Will the Government give publicity to Mr. Cerutty's statement, in justice to that officer ?

talk.start.para: The Prime Minister has supplied the following answers to the honorable senator's questions : -

item.para: I have read the statement as published in the newspaper, to which the honorable senator refers.
Yes, so far as I am aware.
It is not considered that any such action by the Government is needed.

subdebate.1.para: Employment of Returned Soldiers

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that unemployed soldiers, who are not members of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers' Imperial League, are being refused employment on Garden Island, Sydney, by reason of their non-membership of such league?
Will the Minister make inquiries into the matter and ask for a report from the captain in charge of Garden Island?

talk.start.para: Inquiries will be made, and a reply will be furnished to the honorable senator as early as possible.
asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, upon notice -

item.para: Has any copy of the recent trade agreement between Britain and Denmark boon received by the Government?
If so, will the Leader of the Government in the Senate place a copy of such agreement in the hands of each honorable senator?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable senator's questions are as follow : -

item.para: Yes.

The Government is in possession of only a limited number of copies of this agreement, hut arrangements will be made to place a copy on the table of the library where it will be available for perusal by honorable senators.

subdebate.1.para: Inclusion of Queanbeyan

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Interior,. upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that there is a movement in. Queanbeyan directed towards obtaining the inclusion of that area within the boundary of the Federal Capital Territory?
If so, has any official cognizance been taken of the matter?

talk.start.para: PEARCE.The Minister for the Interior has supplied the following answers to the honorable senator's questions : -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: No official representations whatsoever have been made regarding the matter.

talk.start.para: . - by leave - During the first reading debate on the Customs Bill, I promised to have inquiries made in order to ascertain whether any copies of the draft agenda drawn up by the experts preparatory to the World Economic Conference were available. There is some doubt whether we have any right to reprint the document, but I understand that two copies have been placed on the table of the library. I have a third copy, which any honorable senator may see on request.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 13th June (vide page 2274), on motion by Senator McLachlan -

quote.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: . - I have spoken so often on the subject of tariffs, and always to the same effect, that a re-statement of my views should be unnecessary, but I feel that were I to remain silent on. this occasion the reasons for my silence would probably be misconstrued, and I would be placed in a false position. I made my first speech in advocacy of protection in a debating society in Victoria when I was sixteen years of age, and the many intervening years have only served to confirm me in the opinions I then expressed. I can truthfully say that my fiscal faith has never faltered. I have kept the faith, and I hope that, according to my ability, I have fought a good fight in what I believe to be a righteous cause.

speech.para: We are considering this problem at a time when a state of economic uncertainty prevails throughout the world. A great conference is now being held in London, which may or may not have important results. In any case, that gathering has the good wishes of everybody concerned for the welfare of the world, and grievous disappointment will be felt if it fails to find a solution for some of the difficulties which are confronting us.

I am not one of those who blame tariffs for the unfortunate position in which the world finds itself. I believe that the root cause is much deeper and more general ; that tariffs are the effect and not the cause of many of our troubles. One of the purposes of the Economic Conference that is at present being held in London is to secure a reduction of tariffs and the removal of the restrictionson world trade. Although most of the countries of the world are represented at this conference, so far only Great Britain and the United States of America have made public expressions of opinion on the subject, to the effect that they hope that the convention will be the means of finding a market for their products.

Protective tariffs are not new to Australia. For some years prior to federation, Victoria had enjoyed the benefits of a protectionist policy, and it is apparent that, when the Constitution was being framed by the different conventions, and was subsequently submitted to the State parliaments and the people, a protectionist policy for the Commonwealth was in contemplation. There is no clearer evidence of that than the provision in the Constitution which provided for the retention by Western Australia of the control for a period of duties imposed upon commodities imported by that State. As I have always understood it, the purpose of that provision was to enable Western Australia to establish secondary industries within its boundaries, so that it would be in a position to compete successfully with the products of other States. It cannot be said that Western Australia took appreciable advantage of the opportunity then presented to it, with the result that for many years that State has opposed the policy of protection which a majority of the people of the other States have favoured.

talk.start.para: - That is not correct.

- If I am wrong I shall be glad to be corrected by a representative of Western Australia. That State has my sympathy, and I believe that the disabilities from which it suffers under federation require further and fuller investigation.

speech.para: I hope that the results of the Economic Conference which is being held in London will be more favorable to Australia than were those achieved at Ottawa, from which convention we entertained high hopes. I repeat what I have said previously, that I do not blame our representatives who attended the Ottawa Conference for the unsatisfactory results that were obtained. Experience has led me to form the opinion that Great Britain drove a hard bargain with Australia, and that we have not obtained the benefits which we were led to believe would accrue from the agreement which was approved by our representatives, and subsequently ratified by this Parliament. Whether it was a result of that agreement or not, after the pact had been entered into the prices of the products which it principally affects - wheat, meat and butter - fell to lower levels than those which had obtained for years previously.

talk.start.para: - If it had not been for that agreement we should not have obtained any Empire trading benefits.
- That is purely a matter of speculation. We expected to obtain from the Ottawa agreement an immediate and appreciable benefit, which has not materialized.

speech.para: What is the cause of our present economic difficulties? I say without hesitation that they are due entirely to the over-production of primary commodities. Throughout the world it has been proved that a buyer's market exists so far as wheat, wool, meat and butter are concerned.

talk.start.para: - There has been no carry-over of wool.

- Wool has been sold at a price which, we are told, does not pay the growers, proving my contention that it is a buyer's market so far as that commodity is concerned, just as it is with regard towheat, butter, meat and other products. For months past we have read in our newspapers that there has been keen competition at the wool sales held in Australia, and that prices are rising. Yet, strangely enough, the average price of wool appears to remain at about the same level.
- During the past few clays it has risen by approximately 15 per cent.

- Only for odd clips. It is significant that for some months the average price per bale of wool has' not been disclosed by the wool brokers. The Australian wool industry is in its present unfortunate position largely because the buyers have organized to fix prices at a low level. The producers of wool are not wholly blameless. The position was as bad, if not worse, in 1920, when Bawra was established, and when there was a surplus of about 3,000,000 bales of wool. Through the instrumentality of Bawra the producers of wool obtained control of the market and fixed a basic price, as a result of which they waxed fat and dissolved Bawra. They have since repented at leisure. As a result of the wool-broking firms now having assumed control of the position, neither Bawra nor any other selling organization has been formed. It has been mentioned several times during the first and second-reading debates on the tariff that, while the prices of. primary commodities have fallen to unpayable levels, those of goods produced by secondary industries remain comparatively high. After giving the matter a good deal of thought I have arrived at the conclusion that the reason is that the prices of our land products are controlled by the buyers, while those of the products of our secondary industries are, to a large extent, controlled by the manufacturers. The consensus of opinion is that there can be no change in the world prices for primary commodities unless prices or the volume of production are controlled by central authorities. I know that some honorable senators object to Government interference of any kind. A few days ago Senator Elliott referred to the faulty marketing of our butter, for which he blamed the Government, and expressed the opinion that our butter should be put up and sold in Great Britain in pats. Almost in his next sentence the honorable senator objected strongly to any Government interference or control of business. It seems to me that those two statements are incompatible. I am a firm believer in reciprocal trade. I consider that, if everything be taken into account, our purchases from Great Britain are equal to her purchases fromus. Until recently,

speech.para: Great Britain's purchases from Australia have been chiefly of commodities upon which no preference was given, such as wheat, wool, and butter; the goods that we exported had to compete on equal terms with "the products of other countries.

In dealing with the volume of our trade with Great Britain, I propose to advance what I believe to be an entirely new contention; that is, that the many millions of pounds that we pay every year to British bondholders by way of interest, ought to be included in the figures relating to our trade with the Mother Country. In my opinion, money is a commodity, and ought to be treated as such. We have purchased the use of over £500,000,000, and when we discharge our interest commitment, we pay for a commodity in the same sense as when we pay for the goods that we import.

talk.start.para: - Why not preach the reduction of interest?

- That, I believe, is imminent. I cannot see how the British bondholders can refuse the request for a reasonable reduction of interest. I was astonished to learn that the Chancellor of the British Exchequer had objected to- the flotation of a substantial conversion loan. I could have understood an objection to a proposal to raise new money; but a conversion would simply be from one rate of interest to another, and comparatively little money would change hands.
- A substantial amount of new money might have to be raised.
- In the last loan floated there was 41 per cent, of new money.

- That would mean the release of the amount which the new money replaced. In the aggregate, the sum available in Great Britain for other purposes would not be lessened, because the one would balance the other. The position in regard to money borrowed in Australia is quite different from that in regard to money borrowed overseas, ' because the local lenders are, for the most part, heavily taxed to provide the interest on their own money, whereas we can levy no taxation whatever on the £30,000,000 that we pay annually to our creditors overseas, where the interest rate varies from 5 per cent, to 6-£ per cent. In the present position of the money market of the world, such interest rates are extortionate, and, in common fairness, they ought to be promptly reduced without the slightest demur. I read in the press recently statements by the ex- Agent-General for Victoria, and Professor Wallace, of the Sydney University, from which I gathered that the people of Australia are most unpopular in Great Britain.
- So are our cricketers.

- So were their cricketers when in Australia. Why should we be unpopular in Great Britain '? I believe it is largely because of the character of the men who have represented Australia in London. I was pleased indeed to read recently , that Mr. Bruce had put in a good word for Australia and Australians. I. hope that whoever may represent Australia in London in the future, will be a thorough-going Australian, who will not be afraid to speak on our behalf at every opportunity. Professor Wallace says that it would be to the advantage of this country if we had a better opinion of ourselves. I think so, too. I have, heard many adverse opinions in regard to Australia expressed during the debate on this measure,, especially in regard to our manufacturers - their equipment, their methods, even their character. I had the opportunity, while associated for a couple of years with the Department of Trade and Customs, of meeting many manufacturers in Sydney, Melbourne and other centres. The opinion that I formed from personal contact was, that they are all honorable men, who are rendering a great service to Australia, and ave worthy of our confidence and commendation. The position to-day is, that hundreds of thousands of our people are unemployed. But things are no worse in Australia than elsewhere, and our chances of recovery are better than those of countries which devote themselves mainly to primary industries. For many years New Zealand was cited as an example of what could be accomplished in a country that depended upon its land products. In the early months of the depression there were those who contrasted the position in Australia with that in our sister dominion, but the general opinion now of those who speak and write with authority, is that conditions are much worse in New Zealand than in Australia, and that her recovery will be more difficult and longer deferred. Prior to the depression, the per. capita purchases by New Zealand from Great Britain were the highest in the world. In 1929, they amounted to £14 10s. a head, the Irish Free State coming next, and Australia being in third place. The latest figures relating to New Zealand that I have been able to obtain are for the year 1931, in which her purchases from Great Britain droppedto £8 a head. New Zealand has recently appointed a board to inquire into what new industries may be established to provide work for her unemployed. I am sorry to say that the latest figures show that 60,000 adult male workers are registered as unemployed in that dominion. Its published statistics do not include unemployed women and youths. I am sure that no honorable senator can sec any virtue in unemployment. I hope we have not in this country, as apparently they have in the United States of America, people who think that cheap labour is of advantage to industry. I was interested therefore in an article that appeared in the Saturday Evening Post of the 10th December last, from which I quote the following passage: -

quote.para: The twin sister of the cheap labour myth is that which demands a considerable permanent floating supply of idle workers. According to this latter belief, industry cannot flourish unless there are constantly so many idle hands that those who do have jobs can be hold down to low wages through fear of being turned off and ofbeing replaced by others, whose necessity is so great that they think any wage is better than none at all. Beliefs such as this have made a few men rich, and many men poor. Private greed of this sort always creates a public debt that some one must pay. A few for the time may win; society in the long run always loses.

speech.para: I am confident that our experience confirms that statement. Men and women who are fit and willing to work, but who are unemployed for long periods, feel that the world has treated them badly, and consequently have a grudge against Society. That was recognized long ago, and I should like to quote a few lines from
Macbeth upon the point. Macbeth is inquiring into the qualifications of two persons whom he wishes to hire as assassins, and they reply to his questions as follows: -

item.para: Mur. I am one, my liege,

speech.para: Whom the vile blows and buffets of the world
Have so incens'd, that I am reckless what
Ido, to spite the world.

item.para: . Mur. And I another,

speech.para: So weary with disasters, tugg'd with fortune,
That I would set my life on any chance To mend it, or be rid on 't.

That quotation is apropos of a series of articles which appeared recently in the Melbourne Argus to the effect that there were 60,000 unemployed boys in Victoria, and that a substantial increase had taken place in the number of youthful criminals. That statement reveals a serious condition of affairs. I learnt recently from a Melbourne newspaper that a number of University students with Engineering Degrees were working as" labourers at Iron Knob, in South Australia, and that a number of others with Arts Degrees were learning shorthand and typing in the hope of being able to obtain casual employment. That shows how every class of society, and every section of the community, is affected materially and morally by the present position, and it shows us the danger with which we are likely to be faced unless we solve the problem of unemployment and put our people to useful work. It is regrettable that a great many of our citizens who hold responsible positions appear to be more concerned about finding employment for men and women in Bradford, Sheffield, Glasgow and other industrial centres overseas than they are about providing employment for the workers of our own country. It has been urged time and again that in imposing, protectionist duties we need to be careful lest we offend the authorities and citizens of other countries, but I do not think that any other country, in framing its tariff, considers whether offence may be given to us. When Great Britain proposed to change over from freetrade to protection, a number of countries protested, and Mr. Runciman, on behalf of the British Government, answered those protests in a speech which he made in Rome. I regret that I cannot quote his actual words, bur in a communication from London, dated t,ho 4th of December, and published in the Sydney Morning Herald, appeared the following statement -

quote.para: Mr. Runciman virtually warns France that Britain will not hesitate to depend upon her own people. It is a further gesture to interImperial trade unity, giving foreigners their own medicine.

speech.para: In the same article, under date the 5th December, appeared this further statement -

quote.para: The tariff problem was referred to in a speech by the Chancellor of the Exchequer at Newport last night when he said that Britain must claim the right exercised by other countries to direct her fiscal policies according to her own interests.

speech.para: We should follow the example of Great Britain. We, as a people, have tremendous responsibilities. We have a greatcountry, capable of supporting a large population in comfort, and we should not fail in our obligations as a nation. Some persons contend that Australia cannot, support a population of more than about 20,000,000; but such a contention is ridiculous. I am satisfied that Australia can easily support a population of 100,000,000. Our population can be limited only by the quantity of food and raw materials that we are capable of producing, and that quantity is considerably greater than has been previously estimated. Take the position of Italy under the dictatorship of Mussolini. That country is comparatively small, and a great part of its area is not arable; yetlast year it produced 275,000,000 bushels of wheat, or double its production of only a few years ago. The annual consumption of wheat in Italy is 300,000,000 bushels, and at one time that country had to import more than half of its requirements. It is now probable tha', within a year or two Italy will be able to supply the whole of its requirements of wheat. Something of that nature is taking place in almost every country of the world, including Great Britain. Speaking in the House of Commons a few months ago on the question of unemployment, Mr. Ramsay MacDonald said that Great Britain would have to look for the solution of its unemployment problem more to the land than it had hitherto done. Mr. Lloyd George said that instead of paying the dole to people capable of working on farms thb Government should subsidize farmers who were willing' to employ them. According to statistics, the area of land under agriculture in Great Britain to-day is 3,000,000 acres less than it was a few years ago; so we can realize the possibility in that country of a vast increase of primary production, with a consequent restriction of the market upon which wo chiefly depend.

talk.start.para: - Great Britain carries about 60,000,000 sheep.

- Yes, and over 5,000,000 head of cattle. Every European country is endeavouring to produce its own foodstuffs. France at one time was a large importer of wheat, but last year its production exceeded its consumption. It is very evident that we shall stand on the brink of national disaster if we attempt to depend solely or even chiefly upon our primary production. It has been contended that high protective duties tend to increase prices, and the match industry has been quoted as an example. I understand that the offence of the match companies was that they charged 2d. per gross of boxes more than was considered a fair price,- and that the price has now been reduced, to that extent. I do not know whether matches are cheaper than they were.
- They are dearer to-day.

- If they are not cheaper, the extra profit which the manufacturers previously made is now being absorbed by the distributors. It has been proved that the whole of the excess profit of the match companies was expended on the extension of their premises and equipment. We have been, in the habit of comparing the price in Australia with that charged by the great match combine of Europe, but recently we learnt that that combine was able to sell matches cheaply only because of the fact that its principals had defrauded the people of Europe of £100,000,000. So black was the case against these men that Mr. Kreuger committed suicide, another principal fell- out of an aeroplane while it was crossing from England to France, and a third- was recently sentenced to twenty years' penal servitude. There has been circulated as an example of exorbitant duties a leaflet entitled Mystic or Tinsel Mitt. This article is part of. the ordinary kitchen equipment, and I made it. my business to inquire into the effect upon its price of the allegedly high duty. I was told that those purchased for use in my own home, when they first came on to the market, were bought at 8d. a piece. Later the price was reduced to 6d., but when the increased duty was imposed, and the article was made in Australia, the price fell first to 4d., and then to 3d., or five for ls. My experience has been that, when manufacture of an article begins in Australia, the price is immediately reduced to less than that at which it had been previously imported. The other day I had occasion to buy a chemical preparation which I use. I asked the chemist for it, and when he handed it to me he said " ls. 6d., please." I said " Is this the same article for which I used to pay 2s. 6d., and is the 'bottle the same size? " " Oh, yes," he said "it is exactly the same in every respect." "Why, then," I asked, "has the' price been so greatly reduced?" He replied that the article used to be imported from America, but that now i't was made in Australia. I think it is the experience of most of us with regard to a great many articles that,' since importations were excluded under the high tariff imposed in the schedule that has now been partly withdrawn, and manufacturers felt that -they were assured of the Australian market, prices have come down, and we have kept money in the country to the benefit of every one, producers and consumers alike.
- Does that apply in all- cases?
- Does it apply to harvesters?

- I did not say that it applied in all cases; it has applied in very many cases, and sometimes, when prices have been increased in Australia, they have increased also overseas. There has been a marked change in public opinion on this matter recently. Many business people, and some of the leading business houses, are now boasting that most of what they sell is of Australian manufacture. Recently, the chairman of directors of Buckley and Nunn, Melbourne, stated at the annual meeting of shareholders that originally they had been an importing firm, and most of the good's they sold were procured overseas. . At the time of when he was speaking, however, just a few months ago, 70 per cent. of . the goods sold by the firm were made in Australia, and only 30 per cent, were imported. I do not think that I am wrong in saying that Buckley and Nunn are noted for the high quality of the goods they sell. We all know something of such establishments as Woolworth's and Coles. It is the boast of Woolworth's that over 70 per cent, of what they sell is made in Australia, and we know what an infinite variety of commodities they stock. This must of necessity mean a great deal of employment for our people, and we should hesitate before we do anything in the least calculated to supplant Australian products by imported goods. Such action must lead to industrial, economic, and - what may concern some of us - political disaster. I do not want to see the fiery cross raised accompanied by slogans such as " Work for the Workless ", and " Australian Goods for Australian Markets ".

speech.para: The Ottawa agreement has changed very materially our relations with the Mother Country. Previously, those relations rested to a very great extent on a sentimental basis, but now they rest on a business basis, and there is a very general feeling in Australia that such a basis is not satisfactory to us. I hope that I am a loyal Britisher; I think and feel that I am, and I should regret exceedingly if anything were done which would strain our relations with the Mother Country. We must remember, however, that the percentage of Australianborn is becoming greater every year, and, therefore, the population of this country is becoming more Australian and less English, Scotch or Irish. That is a factor which has to be taken into account when we consider what the future holds for us. Owing to that change in the composition of our population, we are more likely to resent any unfair treatment whether in our business, in our politics, or even in our sports. I am convinced that the only safe policy for Australia is selfcontainment so far as is possible. No country can be entirely self-contained, but scarcely any other country can be so self-contained as Australia, because we can produce somewhere in this island contitent practically everything we need. We have every class of soil, every productive range of climate, and our people have abilities equal to those of the people of any other country on the globe.

I know that in this connexion a special plea has been made for what are called the weaker States. They are weaker only because their populations are smaller than those of the three eastern mainland States. If those three eastern mainland States had formed a federation excluding the other three, they would have had a bigger population to-day, that we have in our "six States. They have so much in common that they could have agreed upon a policy which would have been in every respect satisfactory to all. In my opinion, South Australia has very little to complain of, certainly less than has either of the other two States - Tasmania and Western Australia. I remind honorable senators that South Australia gave to this Parliament Mr. .Kingston, one of the staunchest protectionists that we have ever had. The position of Tasmania is different from that of Western Australian and South Australia. In the first place, it is separated from the mainland, and, in the second, its area is small, and much of it, though beautiful to look upon, is unproductive. I do not think that any disabilities have been imposed on Tasmania by federation, but the people of that State are few, and we of the mainland are many. The obligation of the many to help the few is very strong, and I arn sure it is one which will not be shirked. I do think that Tasmania has u claim for a better shipping service, and it is the duty of the Commonwealth Government to see that the shipping companies, which are protected by the Navigation Act, provide a proper service to Tasmania.

talk.start.para: - It would be much better to repeal the coasting trade provisions of the Navigation Act.

- That is something which I do not think will ever come about. When I was a delegate to a conference of the associated chambers of commerce in Sydney last year, I was the only one who spoke against a motion seeking the repeal of those provisions.

speech.para: The same motion was submitted in Hobart recently, and a majority of those present were against it, so that it is evident that 'public opinion on this subject, even among members of chambers of commerce, has changed very materially during the last few months, just as it has changed with regard to the policy of protection. As a rule, the members of chambers of commerce in every country are freetraders.

talk.start.para: - That is absolute nonsense.

- Nowhere is that more pronounced than in the country in which the honorable senator was born. From time immemorial we have heard of the Manchesterschool. Whenever one wanted to refer to extreme freetraders, one spoke of the Manchester school. Yet it was the Manchester Chamber of Commerce which led the way in asking the British Government to introduce a policy of protection for Great Britain. That was followed by requests by the London and Liverpool Chambers of Commerce. Prior to that, the members of the British section attending the conference of the International Chambers of Commerce held at Washington last year reported when they returned that the only way to establish trade equilibrium was by the imposition of customs duties or prohibitions against importations. I was speaking about the disabilities of Tasmania, and I should just like to add-

- I rise to a point of order. In discussing the second reading of the Customs Tariff Bill, is the honorable senator in order in referring to the disabilities of the States or the repeal of the coasting trade provisions of the Navigation Act? I submit that the honorable senator's remarks are not relevant to the motion before the Senate.

speech.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. P. J. Lynch). - The honorable senator is somewhat straying from the subject before the Chair, but I presume that he is following that line of argument in order to illustrate his opinions on the fiscal policy of the Government as embodied in the bill.

talk.start.para: - But for this slight interruption I should have finished what. I had to say with respect to Tasmania. My speech may contain a few irrelevancies, but the speeches of some honorable senators have been almost wholly irrelevant. I trust that the shipping and telephonic communications between Tasmania and the mainland will be improved.
- The honorable senator must connect his remarks with the subject-matter of the bill.
- If those communications are improved, a great many of the disabilities which the Tasmanian people think are imposed upon them by the Commonwealth customs tariff will be removed.
- Tasmanian people believe in the imposition of an embargo on the importation of potatoes.

- I think that all believe in protection for what they have to sell, while some advocate freetrade in those goods which they have to purchase. During the debate I was accused, by interjection, of being a little Australian.
- By whom?

- The honorable senator should ask himself that question. I should be sorry to say or do anything which would lay me open to that accusation. I feel that I am a citizen of a country which is at least potentially great. I have a good opinion of Australia, and of the Australian people, and I am anxious to serve this country, and also to serve my fellow citizens, but I think that that can best be done by establishing industries in .Australia, and maintaining, those industries already established, in order to give employment to our own people. If that were done it would make Australia a better market for Britsh producers than it is at present. An impoverished country is of no use to its own citizens or to- the pf to nlc of any country who wish to trade with it. I believe that the policy of freetrade would impoverish this country, and destroy the market which at present exists for British goods.

speech.para: I have lived most of my life in country districts. I was brought up on a mixed farm in Victoria, upon which we produced almost everything required for table use. We lived particularly well; hut the people of to-day are not prepared to live in the same way as did the small farmers 50 or 60 years ago. During recent years many millions have been spent - much of which has been wasted - by the Commonwealth and the States in settling people on small areas. To endeavour to settle a large number of persons on the land in the present economic condition of this and other countries can be attended only by disastrous results. The opinion is held in some circles that any one can become a successful farmer; but that is an opinion which I do not share. A man must be instinctively fond of farming, or he will never succeed in rural work. I have never known of a person who thought farming work irksome become a successful farmer. I am afraid that, if more people are diverted from the cities to the country, they will become a greater burden on the State than they are at present.

talk.start.para: - What nonsense!
- I am speaking as the result of a great many years experience on the land, and I know that at least 40 per cent, of those who engage in farming pursuits fail.
- No.

- I know that they do. I speak from experience. I have been living amongst those engaged in farming, and I submit that they do not fail because they are unable to obtain reasonable credit. I have known more to fail because credit was too easily obtainable than because it was difficult to secure. In the crisis through which I hope we have, passed, the banks have been ever ready to help those whom they felt they could safely assist. There are many aspects of this subject with which I have not dealt; but I trust that in considering this measure .every honorable senator, regardless of his political beliefs, will realize that his first duty is to Australia.

. - During the four years in which I have been a member of this chamber, I have , heard many interesting speeches; but that of Senator Crawford, who had ministerial experience in a previous government, shows that he is a big Australian.

speech.para: Although Senator Crawford belongs to a different political school from that of myself and my colleagues, it is interesting to note in this instance that at least one honorable senator opposite is not prepared to support the anaesthetical freetrade policy advocated by so many honorable senators. As a Labour senator, I desire to repeat what 1 have said on former occasions that tariff reform in itself will not bring about the final emancipation of the class which I represent in this chamber.

talk.start.para: - What class ? -

- The working class - a class of which I am not ashamed if the honorable senator is. The policy of new protection is embodied in the Labour party's platform ; in fact, it is one of its chief planks. I recognize that tariffs are mere palliatives in the class struggle, and that in. Australia they can take us only a certain distance along the road to the real objective of the Labour party; but it is from that angle that I wish to debate this measure, and I believe that my views will be supported by other Labour senators and the loaders of the Labour movement throughout Australia, whose objective is the emancipation of the workers. What we are up against to-day is the power of the press. In the main, our newspapers arc published for profit, and not for use, and until such time as these press dope machines are prepared to tell the truth to the workers we cannot expect to .make much progress. When I refer to the workers I include, not only those engaged in the mines, factories and fields, out also the great mass of people- who have to work for a livelihood. It is true that there are certain doctors of law in Australia who have not a clear conception of the purpose of an instrument used as a political or industrial palliative, and of it's effect upon that large body of workers who are marching along the road to their emancipation. In the main, the people of Australia find that they have a very hard row to hoe. Of course, we have our friends the doctors of law in all the States.
- They are not so common as that I
- I do not know why Senator Brennan should interject; I was not addressing him.
- Perhaps Senator Dunn meant horse doctors.

. - We may assume that the tariff schedule now before us will be the only one of any size that will be tabled by, this Government during the lii & of this Parliament, for the period for which the Parliament was elected has nearly half expired. Minor alteration* of duties may be made in schedules that will be tabled later; but this schedule will, undoubtedly, be the main tariff product of this Government. It is, therefore, incumbent upon honorable senator* to consider whether it gives adequate expression to the tariff policy put forward by supporters of the Government during the last election campaign. In my opinion it does not, and one of the strongest arguments in support of that opinion is that the items which elicited the. greatest interest and provoked the keenest debate when the schedule was before another place, were those relating to matches and tobacco, the production of neither of which, by any stretch of the imagination, can be regarded as essential to the community, or looked to for the promotion of prosperity in our primary industries.

speech.para: Before proceeding to discuss the schedule, I wish to recapitulate, briefly, the general attitude of the great men of this and other countries towards high tariffs. By quoting the views of leading economists and publicists outside Australia, I do not desire it tq be assumed that I think all the great men are necessarily outside Australia - indeed, I shall quote some Australians. . But the tariff views that have been expressed in the last few years by outstanding men, some of whom have visited Australia, should be worthy of our careful consideration. There can be no doubt that the opinion is widely held among people who are qualified to speak with authority that

Australian duties had become too high, even before the large increases were made by the Scullin Administration. I do not intend to make a historical disquisition of our tariff history from the inception of federation - it would be too lamentable a story from my own point of view. I shall quote first the following motion carried at the Economic Conference held at Geneva in May, 1927: -

quote.para: This conference declares that the time lias come to put an end to increases in tariffs, and to move in thu opposite direction.

speech.para: That was a fairly bald and definite statement, from which it is not easy to get away.

talk.start.para: - A lot has happened since then.

- That is true. Tariffs here and elsewhere have gone much higher since that time. I do not suggest that tariffs alone are responsible for the condition in which we find ourselves to-day; but it is instructive to realize that many of the countries now calling for a downward revision of tariffs were formerly highly protectionist. I refer honorable senators also to the report of the British Economic Mission, though I shall not quote from it in detail. It will be remembered that the conclusionsof that body were, briefly, that the Australian tariff had been pushed probably to its farthest economic point. In 1929, an investigation of the tariff was made by Professors Brigden, Copland and Giblin, and Messrs. Dyason and Wickens, and their findings were published in the book, Tha Australian Tariff. These five scientists approached the consideration of the subject more tolerantly than most of the other investigating bodies had done, and endeavoured to come to a sound economic decision. While I shall not quote extensively from their book, I think the following extracts are not an unfair statement of their opinion: -

quote.para: The evidence' available does not support the contention that Australia could have maintained its present population at a higher standard of living under freetrade.

speech.para: I make my friends of the Labour party a present of that quotation. But these scientists also stated that -

quote.para: The total burden of protection should not be increased.

speech.para: They also said -

quote.para: The adoption of a considerable but not unlimited amount of protection is justifiable on economic ground in the circumstances of Australian industry, but the extreme application of the tariff has undoubtedly been a cause of net loss. Further extensions may involve a more than proportionately increased loss.

speech.para: This is the opinion of experts trained to consider statistical information, and form conclusions from it. I remind honorable senators also that these findings were made before the immense increases in the tariff were made by the Scullin Government.

talk.start.para: - The total amount of protection includes exchange ?

- That is so; but there have been immense increases of duties in consequence of legislative action. In these circumstances, the reductions provided in the schedule now before us are not, in my opinion, nearly sufficient. I direct the attention of honorable senators also to statements made by Sir Otto Niemeyer at the Melbourne conference held in July-August, 1980. That gentleman said -

quote.para: So long as the sheltered trades of Australia insist in taking so large a share of the national dividend, and even an increasingly large proportion as the national dividend drops, the difficulties of unsheltered export trade can only increase.

speech.para: He also said -

quote.para: The secondary producer can attempt to moot this price situation by increased tariff protection, hut this simply means that this protection is achieved at the cost of primary production. The primary producer can attempt to meet the situation by a further depreciation in the exchange.

speech.para: But he went on to say that -

quote.para: Increasing tariff prejudice the primary producer, rising exchange rates prejudice the whole fabric of national finance.

speech.para: Had Sir Otto Niemeyer's advice been followed to a. greater extent and in greater detail, Australia would be in a better position than she is in to-day. I shall refer only briefly to the annual reports made by the Tariff Board, especially in 1931 and 1932, iu which it is stated, in effect, that the attempts to build up inefficient industries by enormous duties tend to encourage the adoption of retaliatory measures by other countries. I shall say something more oil this point later. Those reports embody the views of men who are not in any way antagonistic to the development of secondary industries in Australia. But these men felt compelled to point to the abuse of the tariff system. Their criticism will require a good deal more answering than has been given so far. I also direct the attention of honorable senators to the views of certain prominent publicists. I suppose the two outstanding books which have been written on Australia during the last three or four years are Australia, by Professor Hancock, and The Economic History of Australia, by Professor Shann. These two books are being read in every part of the world, and are likely to continue to be read. The conclusion of both writers is undoubtedly hostile to the present exaggerated and inflated tariffs. I shall not quote extensive extracts to support this statement, but the following remark in Professor Shann's book, which deals with the post-war era, is interesting: -

quote.para: In this access of wealth, Australians one and all talked of making their country more self-reliant.

speech.para: It is a comic thing that while we are ostensibly seeking to make our country more self-reliant, we are actually making it more reliant upon the Government than it has ever been.

talk.start.para: - Before the luncheon adjournment, I quoted a sentence from Professor Edward Shann's Economic History of Australia. The quotation continues -

quote.para: Clever men stampeded the democracy into measures seemingly designed to make our economy a hermit one. The coalition of parties in political power during the post-war decade piled tariff upon tariff in favour of local secondary industries, and ' sponsored crude plans to exploit the Australian market in favour of struggling export industries. . . . The more the policy of a hermit Australia succeeded, the more surely would it bring slothful, intellectual standards, and, as a consequence, material decay, until, with scorn, some sea power from the world where necessity had maintained knowledge and energy knocked in the closed door.

speech.para: That, I suggest, is a quotation which might well be taken to heart. It expresses the opinion of a professor who, so far as I know, has no pronounced political views,' but has considered the whole subject broadly. My final quotation will be from the communique which was issued at the close of a meeting of the organizing committee of the World Economic Conference, which met at the Foreign Office on the 12th May last. At that gathering a resolution to the follow ing effect was unanimously agreed to: -

quote.para: The Governments of the United Kingdom, Germany, Belgium, United States, France, Italy, Japan, and Norway, convinced that it is essential for the successful conclusion of the conference that measures pf all kinds which at present misdirect and paralyse international trade be not intensified pending an opportunity for the conference, to deal effectively with the problems created thereby recognize the urgency of adopting, at the beginning of the conference, a tariff truce, the provisions of which shall be laid down by common agreement.

The said Governments, being further convinced . that immediate action is of great importance, agree and strongly urge all other Governments participating in the conference to agree that they' will not, before 12th June, nor during the proceedings of the conference, adopt any new initiatives which might increase the many . varieties of difficulties now arresting international 'commerce.

speech.para: I have said enough to show that the

Opinion of the leaders of thought in Australia, and throughout the world - speaking apart from politics - is to the effect that the tariff war has become a general menace, as, indeed, I believe it to be", not only to trade, but also to world peace. When. I say this, I am rather diffident about giving my own views on these matters, having regard to the talents of the men whose opinions I have already quoted. Nevertheless, it is the duty of a member of Parliament to come to his own conclusions. I am speaking as one who for many years has been a reasonable tariffist. I know that the word "reasonable " will be cavilled at, and that a definition will be . sought ; but I have always believed that it is not desirable that Australia should be entirely filled with primary producers. We should have our industries reasonably and widely distributed. We should not adopt the line that we are simply to produce primary products and raw materials for use overseas, and not manufacture any of them in our own country.

I shall give a number of reasons why I am opposed to high tariffs in general, and why I consider that the present tariff, in particular, is altogether too high. In the first place, it seems to me that Australia's tariff is not fair to the Mother Country. 1 always approach' the tariff question remembering that, in the last resort, we are dependent for our very existence on the great country from which we have sprung, and on the force which it has had for so long, and which it knows so well- no country, indeed, knows better - how to use as a means, not of offence, but of defence. Only the other day we had word that five vessels of a destroyer flotilla had been lent to us by Great Britain, thereby saving us the expense of providing ourselves with similar vessels out of capital. That loan was welcome, and it was spoken of as a generous act on the part of Britain.I suggest that it is not sufficient to talk of generosity, because such an action on one side deserves response of a similar nature on the other. I think that this tariff schedule is not in agreement with the spirit of the Ottawa Conference. I am not saying for the moment that it is not in accord with the letter of the Ottawa agreement. That contention can, and, no doubt, will, be advanced later; but I remind honorable senators that, when our delegates went to Ottawa, they said they were not in a position to come to any definite arrangement as to details, so far as their country was concerned, and the eventual result was that Great Britain made a number of concessions in regard to individual items. We, on our side, entered into a sort of general agreement which is set out in writing for the sake of convenient reference, but, in itself, is so general that it may, and probably does, lend itself to differing interpretations. In other words, some of the concessions that we obtained were in the nature of extensions of the ranges of goods to which the British preference applied, and others were in the nature of increases of the preference. We pledged ourselves to adhere to certain general principles, and I suggest that it is idle, in these circumstances, for us to say, " We consider that, under the agreement, we have done what is a fair thing." The very fact that these arrangements were so general throws upon us the responsibility of showing that we are really giving Great Britain a fair deal. If we do not do so, the inevitable result will be a certain amount of criticism, in not only the British Parliament, but also the British press, which is, indeed, already being heard. It is not likely that the British Government will make a public statement that, in its opinion, we have failed to perform our part of this agreement; but we shall probably find that it will be impossible, or, at least, exceedingly difficult, to renew it, let alone extend its scope in the future. I deplore the habit, which I notice iscommon, of looking up an article of this agreement, and saying, " We consider that what we are now doing is in accord with article so and so of the agreement." What we have to do is to show that we have carried out the agreement in such a way that, taken by and large, we have given Britain a fair deal.

By our tariff we have provoked a rather marked hostility on the part of foreign nations. It is unnecessary, I suppose, to go into details concerning the resentment to which it has given rise in France and Germany, and of the retaliatory measures to which those countries have resorted. Nor, probably, need I refer to the fact that Belgium is not altogether pleased, for instance, with our attitude to its glass. I suggest that we should take the trouble to look up the statistics, and find out whether we are not exportingto countries such as Belgium, Japan and New Zealand - as, of course, we are - a great deal more than they are sending to us. In 1930-31, New Zealand exported toAustralia merchandise to the total value of £775,000, but the goods which Australia exported to New Zealand ware worth £2,975,000. Our imports from Japan in that year were worth £2,379,000, but we exported to that country goods to the value of £9,500,000. We purchased from Belgium goods to the value of £312,000, yet we exported to Belgium products worth £4,195,000.

talk.start.para: - Principally wool.

- Yes, but that fact does not in any way qualify or weaken my argument. What has to be considered is the balance of trade. It seems to me to be the height of unwisdom, where we have such a tremendous balance of trade in our favour, for us to seize an opportunity of levying an embargo, for instance, on potatoes coming from New Zealand, or to put a very high tariff on glass, even to the point of an embargo, against Belgium. In the case of Japan, we have, apparently, so irritated that country, that it was suggested the other day that a restriction might be placed on the entry of our wool into Japan.
- The embargo on New Zealand potatoes was imposed, not by the Customs Department, but by the health authorities.

-HUGHE S. - That is true, and I am not discussing whether that action was justified; but it has resulted in New Zealand imposing an embargo upon Australian oranges., The agitation which was worked up for the exclusion of New Zealand potatoes from Australia was certainly, to a great extent, political. The object was to exclude such potatoes because they were Now Zealand goods, and the balance of trade between the two countries was not taken into account at all.We recently sent a ship to Eastern seas, and to Malaya, for the purpose of trying to extend our markets there; but how can we expect success in that enterprise? The ship visited Java, whose sugar we do not buy, and found half the sugar mills in Java closed. Is it natural to suppose that Java will have kindly feelings towards us? I do not know whether the ship went to Fiji, but I read in the press the other day that great irritation has been occasioned in that country because of the way in which Australia has observed the terms of the Ottawa agreement with respect to bananas. While with our high tariff we are not doing what I regard as a fair thing to the Mother Country, we are, at the same time, following out the hermit policy of which Professor Shann speaks, and estranging ourselves from the goodwill of the world at large. This is mainly because of our tariff. Two or three years ago, I read in the press that a Labour gentleman named Crofts, I believe, had been to Geneva, and that on his return he said that it was extraordinary to notice that everybody there seemed to be antagonistic to Australia. He added that they appeared to be rather pleased than otherwise to hear that this country was in the throes of depression. There must be some reason for this, and I suggest that it is not far to seek.
- Many who attended the Ottawa Conference came back with the same story.

- When I was in Vienna three years ago, a gentleman, whom I regarded as a respon sible man with some knowledge of public affairs, who would not talk lightly about such subjects, asked me if I could explain why the people of Australia seemed to be more hostile to other countries than those of other parts of the world. Clearly he had the impression that we were definitely hostile to a number of European countries. Whether his opinion was based on our attitude to migration, on our White Australia policy, or on our general tariff policy, I am unable to say.
- Possibly, he had heard about Mr. Lang.
- I doubt it, because great as may be the fame of Mr. Lang, in both Australia and Great Britain, he would hardly have been so well known in Vienna three years ago.

speech.para: Another objection to this high tariff is its serious effect upon the industry of the primary-producing States ; but I shall not dwell upon this aspect of the matter now, because during the last week or two, a good deal has been said about it. Still, we cannot ignore the drift towards secession, which, I am informed, has gathered momentum in my own State, even in the few weeks since the Senate recommenced its sittings. We cannot disregard the fact that population is moving from the smaller and primary-producing States to those States which are benefiting from our tariff legislation, or from government subsidies to an undue extent. To indicate how definite is this movement of population, I may state that the representation of South Australia in the House of Representatives will, probably, be reduced by one member as a result of the forthcoming census, and that additional representation will be given to one of the more powerful and richer eastern States. Any one who wishes to. ascertain to what extent the various States are directly affected by the tariff, need not look further than the report of the Australian tariff economic inquiry which I quoted this morning. In Appendix W of this tariff investigation report, there appear these comments -

item.para: . The effects of the tariff upon different areas, and especially upon the States, are so important that a summary statement is called for . . . The unequal effects between States are probably the most embarrassing consequences of the tariff . . . The established producers in these areas and States have, undoubtedly, been penalized by the tariff. Prom the point of view of the States themselves, the consequences are not less important . . . It is natural that the harmful effects of the tariff should express themselves most acutely as difficulties of State finance . . .

speech.para: The effect of the tariff on States is just as important as its effect on individual industries. Lately, rural industries have been forced to appeal to the Federal Government for some form of assistance, because of the detrimental effect of the tariff. For a similar reason, several State Governments have been practically compelled to ask the Federal Government for what appears to be a favour, but, on the showing of the report from which I have quoted is merely the return of something which has been taken from them by legislative action.

Then we have to consider the load on the primary producers, due to the operation of the tariff. South Australia, as honorable senators are well aware, is essentially a primary-producing State, though it is not the only State that depends almost wholly on primary production. I understand that the position of the farmers in western New South "Wales is, if anything, worse than that of the farmers in my own State, and, therefore, their need for assistance is quite as urgent. We may be told that the Commonwealth Government has done a great deal for them. That, no doubt, is partly true, and as I do not wish to look a gift horse in the mouth, I admit that a certain amount of relief has been given. For example, there have been remissions of sales taxation; but mostly, I should say, of a rather small order. There has also been a reduction of the land tax. This is not a negligible concession, but its beneficial effects are felt even more by city property-holders than by country landowners, so it cannot be regarded as a special concession to the man on the land who is producing wealth for export'.

talk.start.para: - The tax does not fall upon the small fanner.
- That may be true, but it has its effect, nevertheless, on all the rural industries.

speech.para: Then there was the special grant for wheat-growers, over £3,000,000 being provided by the Scullin Administration, and over £2,000,000 last year by the present Government. It is hard to get exact figures dealing with the cost of the tariff to our wheat-farmers, but it works out, possibly, at something like 5d. a bushel; so if the Government gives back to the farmers, in the form of a bounty, 4£d. a bushel in one year, and 3£d. a bushel in the following year, it cannot be contended that this act of justice, for it is no more than that, puts him in any favoured position. It is only making up to him, partially and temporarily, what has been taken from him permanently, with the possibility of the exactions beingincreased.

Is it fair to inflict such liabilities on those who are producing the wealth of this country, forcing them, eventually, to appeal to the Government for exemptions on the ground of hardship? I venture to say that, at the present moment, owing to the tariff, while practically every primary producer in Australia could, with complete justice, claim exemption from some portion of this burden at all events, on the ground of hardship, the majority do not care to exercise their right because of pride, or the possession of a certain amount of capital reserve, or for some other reason.

talk.start.para: - The dairymen and fruit-growers in Tasmania are just as badly hit by the tariff.

- I certainly do not suggest that the two industries which I have mentioned are the only ones that are suffering from our tariff legislation. I emphasized their difficulties because they represent that section of our primary producers who produce by far the greatest part of our overseas wealth.

speech.para: What I should have expected, and what one might reasonably have expected in the circumstances, keeping in mind the knowledge that our manufacturers have presumably been doing very well under the high tariffs imposed in recent years, and hearing in mind also the dreadfully low prices that have been ruling for primary products, was provision in this schedule for relief in respect of the duties on the requirements of primary producers. Even if this provision were of a temporary nature, to operate only during a time of real stress, such as that through which we are now passing, it would have been gratefully acknowledged. If necessary, the secondary industries concerned could have been assisted by some form of bounty. For years past, it has been repeatedly urged that the bounty system as a means to assist industries, is more equitable than an increase of tariff protection, because for one thing, bounty payments are more easily checked. In this tariff, no attempt is made to consider those articles which are required by primary producers, and their chief expense in the production of our export wealth.

Then we have to consider the position of the consumers, who have always been, but I hope will not continue to be, unorganized. How does this tariff press on the ordinary consumer and the man on a fixed salary? To indicate more clearly bow it affects such persons, I direct attention to two or three items which, perhaps, are not the most important in the schedule, but, nevertheless, may be regarded as typical examples. Take, for instance, the ad valorem duties of 30 per cent. British, and 40 per cent, general on medicines, pharmaceutical preparations, including pills, tablets, and even medicines for animals! At a time like this, when so many people are in financial difficulties, and are obliged to go to public hospitals for medical attention, is it. fair to impose a high tariff on medicines, even those required for animals? Then there is the duty on perambulators and go-carts. ^ suppose that every mother, unless she has one already, requires a perambulator for her child if it is of tender years. Is it reasonable to impose a tariff on perambulators of £1 each, or an ad valorem duty of 30 per cent. British and 50 per cent, general, whichever rate returns the higher duty? No one will suggest that the manufacture of perambulators is essential to the future welfare of Australia. I agree that the more perambulators there are in use in Australia, the better it will be for this country ; but it is not essential that they should be manufactured here. To show how unbiased I am in this matter, I do not even know where perambulators are made in Australia, and what is more, I do not care. It is a gross injustice to penalize in this way every Australian mother who presents an additional child to this country at a time of such great financial difficulty.

I turn now to the duty on rabbit traps. This may not appear to be an important item, but I assure honorable senators that it is by no means unimportant, because I know, from personal experience, that during the last year or two, rabbits have been increasing to such an extent that, in some country districts, they have become a perfect plague. A great many men who are unable to secure employment, not only in country districts, but also in our cities, have quite wisely decided that it is better to go trapping rabbits and selling them than to remain in populous centres, monotonously drawing what has been provided by Governments in the form of sustenance relief. One could mention a number of items, including cotton and. wool textiles, agricultural implements, and boots, on which the duties are too high. At a time when so many people are almost without boots, why is there an ad valorem duty of 45 per pent. upon boots from Britain? That duty should be removed, even if compensation had to be given hi some other way. I am not advocating a radical scrapping of duties; but I say that the Government would be justified in suspending the tariff on the things which the primary producer requires, even if that meant paying a bounty to keep certain manufacturing firms going. An ad valorem duty of 45 per cent, on boots is absurd. I have already mentioned some of the classes of persons who do not benefit from the high duties. Who does benefit from them? It may be said that the manufacturers and their employees reap advantage from a high tariff, and, therefore, it is only right that we should consider what part they play in the community. That can be calculated adequately only by ascertaining what they add to our common wealth by their exports.

talk.start.para: - It is questionable whether the manufacturers benefit, because high tariffs induce so many to engage in manufacturing that they are, as it were, forced to cut one another's throats.

- That remark would apply to the primary .producers as well as to the manufacturers, except that for every protected manufacturer who is forced to the wall there are probably three or four primary producers who fail.

speech.para: I shall not weary the Senate by quoting a lot of figures; but I point out that, in 1913, Australia's exports of primary products were valued at £73,000,000, compared with less than £2,500,000 in the case of manufactured products. Seventeen years later - in 1930-31- the respective values were £86,750,000 and under £3,500,000. During the ten years from 1920-21 to 1929-30, agricultural products comprised 24½ per cent., pastoral products 52 per cent., and manufactured products 3½ per cent. of our total exports. In the light of those figures, what justification is there for increasing the already high protection given to that section of the community which produces only 3½ per cent. of the country's wealth, especially when by so doing we place the 56½ per cent., represented by the agriculturists and pastoralists, in a most iamentable position ?

One could continue to expose the inequities of the present system, but I shall leave that subject for the present. The Tariff Board's reports show clearly that many manufacturers have been greedy of profits, and have sought excessive rates of duty. I do not suggest that Australia is without manufacturers who are both good and capable; but I am concerned that our fiscal policy is altogether out of balance, and it ought to be righted more rapidly than it is. While the smaller primary producer makes greater demands and indulges in a certain amount of log-rolling, the wool-growing industry remains unprotected. The Wool Committee's report has scarcely been mentioned of late. The wheat-growing industry is in a similar plight. Many of our primary producers are only able to eke out a bare living, and others can scarcely do that. Those who are carrying on are able to do so only by reason of the assistance afforded by country storekeepers, State moratoriums, debt adjustment acts, farmers' relief acts, and by using up what little capital they have acquired. I shall not, however, make the story too long or too sad, although, every week, properties are becoming more and more encumbered, and the smaller men particularly are experiencing greater difficulty in borrowing money to enable them to keep going. Improvements are being neglected, or are deteriorating, rabbits are increasing, and land to a great extent is unsaleable. The result of all these, things is that little or no opportunities exist in rural districts for giving work to others. At this stage I pause for a moment to refer to the idea which is becoming more and more accepted - and which I suggest is encouraged by this schedule - that the way to overcome our difficulties is by increasing the number of employees in urban industries, notwithstanding that those industries have to receive State protection in order to exist at all. That is not the thing to do. Were it not that the man on the land has been placed in an almost impossible position, through no fault of his own, he would be able to provide more work than is now possible. Unfortunately, the policy of the country seems to be that the primary producer shall bear the burden, and accept the risk of prices rising in time to avert disaster.

I now turn to the printed Record of the Lyons Government. So far as I am aware, it does not contain any statement of the Prime Minister's policy speech; but it does set out the seven points which were announced by Mr. Lyons and published in the press on the 28th March, 1931. Speaking generally, those were the points which I emphasized when I spoke in various parts of the country prior to the last election. Among those seven pointswere the following: -

item.para: The restoration of a balanced national budget on a basis of equality of sacrifice, to be progressively effected as the financial capacity of the community permits.
Economically sound tariff policy with effective preference to Great Britain and inter- dominion reciprocity.
He-employment of the people by the encouragement of productive enterprise.

speech.para: Are we to assume that only the secondary industries are productive enterprises? That is not how I have interpreted the term. The last point of the policy announced by Mr. Lyons was -

quote.para: Immediate assistance to the man on the land by providing real money, to be expended on keeping Australian landin profitable production.
