speech.para: I read those four points, and then I look at this schedule, and, try as I may, I cannot regard the latter as an adequate carrying out of the former.

I welcome the decision of the Government to afford the Senate an opportunity to discuss the protective incidence of exchange and primage before this bill is finally disposed of. We should be better equipped to discuss that subject were we in possession of the Tariff Board's report on it. Personally, I should prefer to have the board's report before us now. Should the schedule pass through the Senate practically unaltered, there will probably be a claim that the schedule is approved, and that therefore there is no need to make effective any reduction of exchange which the Tariff Board might have suggested; and, alternatively, in the event of the Senate deciding that some duties should be reduced, it might be suggested that that result should render unnecessary some concession in the matter of exchange. I hope that the Government will consider the suggestion made by Senator Kingsmill last night. Since I have not yet had time to consider carefully either the abbreviated account of the contents of the report, or the Government's proposals, I content myself with saying that at this stage my concern is largely that we shall not be held guilty of acting shabbily in regard to British preference. If the Government decided that any revision of the exchange should apply only toitems under the British preferential part of the tariff, a tremendous amount of juggling with foreign exchanges would be saved, and, in addition, Great Britain would be given a slight preference over all other countries, except, perhaps, those with which Australia had entered into trade agreements.

Some one has asked whether exchange is really a part of the tariff at all. It is, at least, a sideline of the tariff. In the Melbourne Argus of the 9th June, it is reported that the New Zealand Government, in appointing a commission to investigate the customs tariff of that dominion, included as one of the items of reference, " The relations of the tariff to rates of exchange ruling in New Zealand and other countries". No one will deny that these subjects are interlocked.

Where are we travelling in industrial matters? In my opinion, an industrial community is not the best community to have in any country. Whatever the misery that might have existed in England before the great industrial revolution there, and although the revolution brought wealth to the country and alleviated some of its distress, I suggest that a really happy and prosperous country is one in which the people live, not in masses in the cities, working in factories, but in more healthy surroundings in rural districts. Australia is not a country in which the population must necessarily be congested and thrown together. Because of its immense area, Australia's natural development should be in the country districts rather than in the towns and cities.

I suggest that these high tariff schedules, which are placing a great burden upon the primary producers, are steadily driving men out of the country into the cities. From an examination of statistics dealing with South Australia for the last ten years, I find that in only about three country towns of that State has the population increased during that period, two of them being what might be termed fashionable resorts. People are being attracted to the city because of the amenities offering in urban centres, greater advantages for education - those, fortunately, are now also being carried into the country - and, because of the unfair distribution of the gains which may be made. I was reading recently an address on SirWalter Scott by Sir Mungo MacCallum. Scott, as honorable senators opposite will recollect, was a tory and there are some who will say that a tory must necessarily be wrong in his opinions. However, Scott was not always wrong, and I give this view for what it is worth. The extract reads -

quote.para: He (Sir Walter Scott) detested political change, and that with greater vehemence because of the upheaval in France. He eyed industrial progress askance, as in his view it meant the triumph of machinery and competition over friendly use and wont and comradelike give and take. The only feature of contemporary Scotland with which he had hardly any sympathy or acquaintance, was the growth of her manufacturing and trading centres. . . The following sentence from one of his private letters might have been written by the author of the Fors Clavigera - "Manufactures are transferred to the great towns, where a man may assemble five hundred workmen one week and dismiss them the next, without having any further connexion with them than to receive a week's work for a week's wages, nar any further solicitude about their future than if they were so many old shuttles." {Extension of time, granted".] Is that the sort of Australia that we wish to evolve, or that it is desirable to evolve; a country in which tremendous areas of land are available, although we force our people into congested city areas, to work in offices and factories? Is not Australia a land of open spaces and immense distances; a land where any man of our people can go out and take the advantages IIi at it offers, and where something of those qualities which are to be found in the seaman or the man who has lived all his days in the country, may be his, too?

talk.start.para: .- £ listened to the speech of the Minister with a great deal of interest, and particularly to the extracts which he quoted from the draft annotated agenda which lias been submitted by the preparatory commission of experts for the monetary and economic, conference that is now being held in London. There were many things which the honorable senator read with which I agree; I am sure that the honorable senator would have read many other extracts to us had time permitted him to do so. I, too, should like to quote from this annotated agenda some of the views that have been put before the World Economic Conference whose deliberations, I hope, will have a great bearing on the economic welfare of the world. At page 23, section 1b, there appears the following passage: -

quote.para: Restrictions on international trade, whether they take the form of prohibitions or of quotas or licences, have in recent years become exceptionally widespread, and are so numerous that they now constitute an almost insurmountable barrier to international exchanges. They have brought about an unprecedented reduction in international trade and threaten it with complete paralysis.

speech.para: There are many matters in the document which I should like to read; but I shall just pick out a few of the high spots. At page 26, dealing with "Tariff and Tariff Policy" the agenda reads -

quote.para: The tariff policy which has been followed by many countries in the past has been greatly aggravated in recent years. This tendency has contributed largely to the disorganization of world conditions. In respect of tariff policy and treaty policy, as in the case of import restrictions, the conference must seek to modify existing practices and to secure the adoption of more liberal methods.

speech.para: While at page 27 this statement occurs -

quote.para: The object of the conference, as far as tariff policy is concerned, must, therefore, be to reach a general agreement for the reduction of tariffs, and to maintain more moderate tariff policy in the future.

speech.para: At page 28 these -words deal with "Reduction of Tariffs" we read -

quote.para: To bring about a general reduction of tariffs, two ways are open, the advantages and drawbacks of which have 'been exhaustively studied by the Economic Committee of the League of Nations - the system of reduction by percentages, and the system of reduction to a uniform level.

speech.para: I shall give one other short extract which appears at page 29, and is as follows: -

quote.para: The objects which States should have in view are, as has been indicated, the reduction of their customs tariffs, and the adoption of a more moderate policy.

speech.para: No more important statement of the case for a reduction of tariffs could have been produced than this document, nor could the' opinions of this responsible body of men have been couched in more arresting language. My mind goes back to the 1927 conference, which was held in Geneva, to deal with a similar condition of affairs. Nearly all the leading countries were represented, and all were agreed on the general principle that tariffs were altogether too high; thai drastic reductions must be made; that there should be uniformity in customs classification; that prohibitions should be abolished, licences, quotas, and such like set aside, and that these matters should be controlled by way of tariff.

Then I come to the Tenth Assembly of the League of Nations, at which the two predominant notes were Pan-Europe and tariff peace. It will be remembered that " the Right Honorable William Graham, who was at the time President of the British Board of Trade, gave a practical turn to the debate when he propounded a plan for the reduction of customs duties by the conclusion of a tariff peace convention. The suggestion caught the attention of all who were at the conference, and it was decided to hold such a convention. That was done, the gathering beginning on the 17th February, 1930, and concluding on the 24th March of the same year. It was attended by the leading statesmen and the great economists of the world. It was felt by all that, by continually erecting high tariff walls, the nations of the world were creating an economic cataclysm; that economic nationalism had practically gone mad. As a result of that convention, a commercial treaty was signed on the 24th March, 1930, by the representatives of the principal nations of the world. Unfortunately, matters altered in 1929, and began to get worse in 1930, so that circumstances worked against the proposal, and practically nothing has been achieved by the convention. I am afraid that a similar condition of affairs may again come about.I do not think that the majority of the nations will reduce their tariff walls unless they are forced by desperation to do so, but I think that economic factors are appearing that will, in the near future, compel them to do that which is so urgently needed for the benefit of the world. Then will the nationsbe released from economic bondage.

I come again to the economic conference that is being held in London, and I shall read from the introduction to the draft annotated agenda, which puts the position as these men of international fame see it.

talk.start.para: -Will the honorable senator read the list of the nations that are represented at the conference?

- The list of members of the preparatory commission of experts is given at page 35, and includes Germany, Belgium, the United Kingdom, China, the United States of America, France, India, Italy, and Japan. In addition, there are present at the conference other experts who had been invited by the preparatory council to attend, and certain international organizations which have taken part in the work of the preparatory commission. After serious consideration of world affairs, those representative men describe in the follow ing words the conditions with which we are faced: -

quote.para: Before setting forth the problems which require solution, we wish to call attention to the gravity of the situation with which the world is confronted. Unemployment has recently been estimated by the International Labour Office as involving at least 30,000,000 workers. Even this huge total, which does not include the workers' families or other dependants, is probably an underestimate. The burden of suffering and demoralization resulting from unemployment of such proportions is appalling. Wholesale commodity prices - expressed in gold - have declined since October, 1929, by roughly a third; raw material prices on the average by 50 to60 per cent. In the middle of December, at Winnipeg,the price of wheat fell to the lowest level recorded in any primary market for wheat during the past four centuries. Such price-declines have produced profound disturbances in the economic system. They have thrown completely out of adjustment prevailing costs of the various factors of production, have made business enterprise generally unremunerative, and have seriously disorganized practically all the world markets. World stocks of agricultural products and of other raw materials continue to accumulate. The index of world stocks for 1932 was double that for 1925. Huge accumulations thus overhang some of the principal markets and burden the processes of orderly price re-adjustment. Industrial production has been drastically curtailed, particularly in those trades producing capital equipment. The depths which have been reached in some instances are illustrated by the position of the United States steel industry, which, at the close of 1932, was operating at only 10 per cent. of capacity.

speech.para: It is obvious that those gentlemen have come to the conclusion that matters are in a desperate position. Half of the agenda deals with tariffs, tariff walls, tariff restrictions, and prohibitions. That makes one pause for a moment, and think. The ideology of the high protectionist can be classified into two main series, which have been taken up by the masses, and have become an effective means of propaganda in favour of protection. The first is, security; and the second, naturally, social considerations. On the question of security, it is averred that, without sufficient tariff protection, it is not possible to maintain the manufactures that are necessary to the welfare of any community, and that we should be subject to the vagaries of an outside market. I do not think I need argue that point, other than to say that a man who does not grow fruit may still purchase it from a fruiterer.

On the question of social considerations the argument is that, unless manufacturers are protected against the low-wage countries, they must go to the wall; that we must make customs duties so high that they balance, not only the wage rate, but also the whole costs of production. This argument cannot stand criticism, but the important thing is that it sounds comprehensible and is accepted by the masses. Let us assume that we have to compete with countries in which low wages are paid. What about the obverse side of the medal - the primary producer, who has to sell his commodities in competition in markets which are supplied by those lowwage rate countries? If the secondary producer has to be protected against those who labour in lower social conditions than exist in Australia, surely the primary producer also must be protected, because he has to sell his products to such people.

talk.start.para: - That is being done to a very large extent in Australia.
- I have not found it to be so.
- That is the main purpose of the Economic Conference which is sitting in London to-day.

- I have read several extracts in relation to the proceedings of that conference, and not one deals with the point raised by the honorable senator. It surely is obvious that if we maintain high tariff walls, a balance must be preserved by giving to the primary producer a certain proportion of the money that we receive as a consequence of the maintenance of the status of our secondary industries. If we restrict trade, if we interfere with the flow of goods, surely we shall be in serious trouble before long. It is said that tariffs make for greater employment. Is not that a fallacy? Is it not perfectly obvious that inadequate markets make for unemployment? To me, an adequate market is one that absorbs a volume of the production necessary to enable every one to maintain a decent standard of living, and has little to do with the tariff. If we had a tariff wall as high as it is possible to build one, the manufacturer still would not be able to carry on unless he had an adequate market in which to sell his goods. Therefore, if world trade is restricted and kept within the confines of the different countries, Australia and the rest of the Empire will be placed in a difficult position.
- It is in that position now.

- I agree with the honorable senator ; and we must do something to get it out. I sincerely trust that the Economic Conference, at present sitting in Loudon, will sign an agreement that will induce the different countries represented at it so to reduce tariffs that there will be a freer flow of trade and the markets of the world will be open to all the peoples in it.

. - I have listened attentively to the speeches of Senators Millen and Duncan-Hughes, and am at a loss to follow the line of argument they have adduced. The Leader of the Senate (Senator Pearce) also referred to the question of exchange, and said that no country in the world had yet attempted to deal with it. I cannot see that that furnishes a reason for our neglecting to take action; but I am content to let the matter rest until the report of the Tariff Board on the protective incidence of primage and exchange is made public. All that I and my party are concerned about is the welfare of Australia. We desire to create in this country an Australian sentiment, and, to do that, we must offer an inducement to the people to buy locally-produced goods. If it is not possible to convince them of the wisdom of purchasing goods, in the production of which employment is provided for their fellow Australians, it must be made impossible for them to buy what is imported from foreign countries. There should be sufficient warrant for a tariff that will prevent the purchase of cheaper goods by those who are disinclined to help their own country. We realize the difficulty of putting such a policy into operation ; because, while the present paltry living wage continues, some persons must naturally buy in the cheapest market, even though the goods they purchase are inferior to those produced in Australia. Another aspect of the tariff question is our trade balance abroad. We have committed ourselves to certain interest payments. We have assured those of other countries who have sent their goods to Australia that we shall pay our way. We have also pledged our word to the payment of every shilling of interest that we owe. We cannot pay in gold, consequently we must find other means, and the only means which offers is the export of our surplus primary production. I realize that not many of our secondary products are exported. But I also know that this is a very young country, which has made wonderful strides in its production. As a matter of fact, with the exception of three or four commodities, we produce all that we require. One of the exceptions is petrol and oil products; and it was proved beyond the shadow of a doubt, while the Scullin Government was in office, that petrol can be produced at Newnes for8d. a gallon. Senator McLachlan smiles.
- I wish that the honorable senator were right.
- I say to the honorable senator, do as the Scullin Government did - give it a go.
- It will be " given a go ", but on sound lines on this occasion.

- Under the Scullin Government, it was on sounder lines than those on which the honorable senator proposes to place it. The Government has endeavoured to hand over to private enterprise the control of the Newnes project. The Scullin Government proposed to expend£1 for every £1 expended by private enterprise.
- The Commonwealth went into the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited on a fifty-fifty basis, with disastrous results.
- That is the responsibility of the Government, whose duty it is to see that a fair deal is obtained from its own concern.
- That matter is now being investigated.

- When it was previously proposed to appoint a royal commission to inquire into the petrol industry generally, I expressed the belief that no result would be achieved. In the present case, I say that we are only sending good money after bad.
- We ought to be able to obtain all the information we require from the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited.

- Exactly, and the Government will fall down on its job if it does not obtain that information. The Scullin Government was defeated because it would not appoint a royal commission to do what could be done by a departmental inquiry. We have in the public departments men who are capable of performing this service. If the representatives of the Commonwealth on the Commonwealth Oil Refineries Limited are not capable of learning the facts, it is the duty of the Government- to recall them. The biggest part of our petrol and oil supplies comes from the United States of America, with which country our trading positionis so serious as to warrant any action by the Government to counteract it. Another commodity that we cannot produce in this country, so far as I know, is tea.
- Tea can be grown in Australia.

- As, with a couple of exceptions, we can produce all necessary commodities, we may live entirely without the assistance of the outside world. I consider that Australia is a child of the British Empire, and every child which fends for itself has the approval of its parents. But we are waiting, not only for the parent, but also for our enemies, to tell us what we should do, and to see what they are doing. Exchange is a factor which favours the present Government, but did not favour the Scullin Government from the outset of its career. When the Scullin Administration endeavoured to increase the flow of money in this country, by releasing credits, the party that now comprises the Government was opposed to it; but, immediately that party obtained control of the treasury bench, it agreed that the banks should increase the exchange rate, and that had the same result. When we proposed to take similar action, Sir Robert Gibson was called to the Bar of the Senate, and was asked if there were no other way out. That, at all events, was the excuse offered by the then Opposition, who knew in their hearts that they were doing wrong, and that they had no case.
- Was not that action taken in order to obtain information?
- The questions to be asked were handed toSir Robert Gibson before he reached this chamber.
- No.

- The then Leader of the Opposition (Senator Pearce) admitted that he gave Sir Robert Gibson some idea of the questions that he would be asked. Honorable senators know perfectly well that in view of the straitened financial position of Australia at that time, the Scullin Government had no alternative but to increase the tariff in a desperate attempt to rectify the adverse trade balance.
- It was panicstricken.

- There was no panic. The Scullin Government did more than this Government has done to provide employment for the people. This country cannot turn the corner to prosperity until the problem of unemployment is at least partially solved. The tariff can be used to some extent to relieve unemployment, but it is merely a temporary palliative. Although we have hundreds of thousands of people unemployed, imports are still flowing into this country. If we are to provide employment we must manufacture our own requirements, and by increasing the wages bill, more money will be put into circulation, and additional employment will follow. The tariff must be so framed as to give an impetus to Australian manufacturers. Only in that. way can it be of benefit to Australia.
- What goods are being imported that can be made here ?

- Many of the imports that are entering this country could be manufactured here. All of our requirements, with the exception of one or two articles, could be manufactured by our own people. Unless the tariff is used to encourage our secondary industries, it merely provides employment for people in other parts of the world.We should not send a pound of greasy wool out of Australia. Our wool before it is exported should be scoured in order to save the freight on the grease. It is said that a suit of clothes contains 7 lb. of wool. The actual worth of so much wool at1s. a lb. is only 7s., whereas we pay £7 or £8 for the complete suit.
- The overseas manufacturers of wool will not purchase scoured wool if they can obtain greasy wool.
- They make a greater profit by doing their own scouring.
- They do not. They prefer to do their own scouring.

- I have heard some honorable senators say that wool is sold on the open market, and is subject to genuine competition, but I contend that there is no competition, because, usually, the wool is sold in split lots. I am against sending either greasy or scoured wool out of Australia. We should manufacture woollen clothing and export it overseas.

speech.para: I come now to the question of the trade balance and the payment of our overseas obligations, particularly to Great Britain. For the eight years during which the Bruce-Page Government held office, our adverse trade balance averaged £14,000,000 annually. The Scullin Government had every justification for taking drastic action to rectify that enormous adverse trade balance.In order to rectify the trade balance, and, in addition, to meet our overseas commitments amounting to some £50,000,000 annually, that Government found it necessary to place a tariff barrier round Australia. Any country which requires our wool and wheat will buy those commodities, no matter how high our tariff wall may be. Sentiment does not enter into business, and that was clearly shown when Great Britain bought wheat from Russia merely because the price was lower than that of dominion wheat. We have in Australia a great opportunity to expand our home market. We have 100,000 men and women unemployed and not in a position to purchase Australian manufactures. They cannot even afford to buy boots. In prosperous times, Australia was able to manufacture in six months its requirements of boots for twelve months. And what would happen to the local boot manufacturers if imported boots were allowed to enter this country free of duty?

talk.start.para: - Who has suggested that imported boots should enter Australia free of duty ?

- Honorable senators who support the Government are complaining that the duty of 45 per cent, is too high. They say that the rate should be a fair one, but they do not suggest 20 per cent., 10 per cent., or 5 per cent. Do they think that we can compete on an equal basis with low-wage countries, and, at the same time, maintain our standard of living?
- They will not be happy until our standard of living is reduced.
- They will.be most unhappy if ever this country is called upon to compete on an equal basis with low-wage countries.
- As a matter of fact, it was the present Government which prevented Japanese gum boots from being imported into Australia.

- It took this Government a long time to make up its mind whether it would continue the embargo placed, by the Scullin Government on the export of our stud sheep to Russia. As a loyal Australian, I am prepared to do everything within my power to make this nation prosperous. Our duty is to put the interests of our own manufacturers before those of foreign manufacturers. If we are to maintain a favorable trade balance, and meet our commitments abroad, we must send out of this country at least £15,000,000 worth of goods over and above the value of our imports. The only way in which we can meet our overseas obligations is by the export of gold or goods. The Scullin Government changed an adverse trade balance of £14,000,000 annually into a favorable trade balance of £11,000,000. That was a tremendous achievement of which the Labour party is justly proud. But if we fill the warehouses of this country with imported goods, we shall, within a few years, find ourselves in the position which faced the Scullin Government when it took office. We shall have an enormous adverse trade balance, and practically no money in the Treasury with which to meet our commitments. We shall then be forced to use that money for the purpose of paying interest to those who have accumulated the credit, and the burden will be heavier than before. I have here some figures prepared by the Commonwealth Statistician showing how our trade has gone against us over a number of years.
- Will the honorable senator also give the employment figures in secondary industries over the last few years ?

- There has been an increase in unemployment, I do not deny, but I am not for a moment endeavouring to trace a connexion between bur overseas trade balance and our domestic unemployment situation. The honorable senator knows very well, if he would admit it, that the tariff is not responsible for unemployment, or for driving the people from the country to the city. The fact is that there is little employment offering in the country for our people. Some mention was made of rabbittrapping, and perhaps if the Government would pay a bounty of 2d. or 3d. a pair on rabbits, more trapping would be done. The figures prepared by the Statistician are as follow: -

speech.para: It will be seen, therefore, that our adverse trade balance has averaged £14,000,000 a year over this period, equal to a deficiency of ll£ per cent, on our imports. That was the position which confronted the Scullin Government when it assumed office, and that was one of the reasons why the tariff was raised. Even at that time the warehouses throughout Australia were full of imported products. Employment might have reacted more quickly to the measures taken by the Scullin Government had it not been for the stocks of accumulated goods. The manufacturers in Australia could not get going properly because, while those accumulated stocks remained to clog the market, there was not sufficient demand for the locally-made article. . Had it not been for this, the Government's hope that employment would be immediately found for 100,000 people might have been realized. For the two years following the appointment of the Scullin Government, the trade figures were as follow : -

That is the justification of the Scullin tariff. It is necessary that we should do even better than that if we are to balance our national budget, and meet our interest commitments abroad. That is the allimportant question facing Australia today. Everybody agrees that our troubles are largely caused by the enormous interest bill we have to pay, and the taxes levied to meet it.

talk.start.para: - Taxation represents 28 per cent, of our production.

- That is so. If we now reverse the Scullin Government's tariff policy, our overseas indebtedness will continue to pile up. We shall have to fund our overseas indebtedness, and the interest on that money will be added to the interest bill we already owe. How, then, can we ever hope to get" out of our difficulties? I believe that Great Britain would appreciate any move we could, make with a view to coming to some satisfactory arrangement for meeting our obligations. We have no desire to repudiate our debts; but if Great Britain, or any other country, is going to make a dumping ground of Australia for its surplus products, we shall have to repudiate. We shall be forced into such a position that it will be impossible .for us to pay. That is one reason why we should preserve the essentials of the Scullin tariff; the other, of course, being that it is necessary to provide employment for our own people.
- What about reversing the process, and looking for secure markets for our products ?

- I appreciate the difficulty of finding markets, but the honorable senator evidently loses sight of the important fact that most countries in the world to-day are looking for markets abroad just as we are. They are all seeking some place in which to dump their surplus products. Because - of the improvement of machinery, and of production methods due to amalgamations, &c, goods are being produced in larger quantities, and at cheaper prices, than ever before, and all the producing countries are desperately seeking a market for their output. We realize, of course, the stupidity of trying to sell wheat to Argentina, or rice to China, although we already have a surplus of rice in this country after only a year or two's production. Even Great Britain has at last decided to erect a tariff wall, a fact that is causing a good deal of anxiety to other countries. She has determined that she no longer will be a dumping ground for goods from other countries. I was reading in the press the other day that, since Britain had taken measures to protect her local primary producers, the price of pork had increased by 50 per cent. Britain is learning that she can produce a great deal more from the land than was thought possible.

speech.para: That brings me to the subject of placing people on the land in Australia. From the speeches of some honorable senators, it would appear that, in order to solve the unemployment problem in the cities, it was only necessary to tell those who are out of work to pack up their kit and get on the land. I remind honorable senators that, even the country towns of New South Wales, and probably of the other States too, are, to a large extent, land-locked. The big land-owners control the land right up to the doors of the towns, and, even if the small man is willing to go on the land, he can do so only by paying so high a rent to those who own it that it would not be worth his while. If honorable senators really wish to know what the position is in regard to land, let them note the number of applications received whenever blocks of land are thrown open for selection. They will then realize how many thousands are anxious to get land, and how little land is available. The Labour party realized years ago that it was necessary to break up the large estates. With that end in view, it imposed the land tax, which resulted in the breaking up of large holdings, and the placing on the land of many persons who previously had no hope of ever getting there. If the Government wishes to get people on the land it should make land available on which they can settle. If it will not do anything to improve the lot of the man on the land, there are many "ways in which relief can be given. It should tax land-holders who are not producing. There is no need to find a market for the commodities now produced. There is already a market here, but the Government should make it possible for the Australian people to purchase the goods they require. The only way out of the difficulty is to provide them with profitable employment. The protection of our secondary industries is a means by which employment can be provided.

I support the second reading of the bill, because I realize that the duties which it imposes do not differ very materially from those imposed by the Scullin Government. If I had my way I would prohibit the importation of all goods that can be manufactured in this country, and in doing so I would be rendering a great service to Australia generally, and to the working class in particular.

talk.start.para: . - I make no apology for quoting from the draft annotated agenda prepared by the preparatory commission of experts for the World Economic Conference now sitting in London, to which reference has already been made by the Minister in charge of the bill (Senator McLachlan) and Senator Millen. I regard this draft agenda as a document of great importance. It should be published in full, but I regret that that is impracticable.
- It is not the property of the Government.

- I understand that that is the position, and that to publish it in full would be a breach of faith. It is advisable, however, that certain extracts from the report should be incorporated in Hansard, particularly in connexion with tariff matters which we are now debating. When discussing tariff matters we should not restrict ourselves to particular customs duties such as are embodied in this bill, but should also consider the manipulation and regulation of exchange, quotas, embargoes, bounties and subsidies, all of which could, I think, be covered by this bill. I shall endeavour to confine my remarks to one or two of these subjects. According to a statement on page7 of the agenda to which I have referred, the main questions for the conference as set out in the. Lausanne resolution of 15th July, 1932, were as follows : -

item.label: (a)
item.para: Financial questions -

speech.para: Monetary and credit policy.
Exchange difficulties.
The level of prices.
The movement of capital.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Economic questions -

speech.para: Improved conditions of production and trade interchanges, with particular attention to tariff policy.
Prohibitions and restrictions of importation and exportation, quotas and other harriers to trade.
Producers' agreements.
On the same page the following paragraph appears: -

quote.para: In stressing the necessity for concerted action, we do not wish to suggest that nothing can be accomplished before the conference meets. On the contrary, the success of the conference will depend in a great measure upon the vigour with which the participating governments enter upon preliminary negotiations in the meantime. The prospects of substantial all-round success in the necessarily complex and multilateral conference discussions will be greatly enhanced if, in the intervening months, preliminary negotiations have cleared the way for reciprocal concessions.

speech.para: This document was issued on the 20th January, 1933, but what has happened since then? Many countries have raised tariff and other barriers in order to give them something with which to bargain at the World Economic Conference. Germany, for instance, has declared a moratorium on all debts due before 1931. France has imposed many quotas, especially against British goods, in order to provide her with some bargaining powers at the conference. The United States of America seems to have deliberately devalued the dollar for the same purpose, and Japan has also devalued the yen to such an enormous extent that at present it is worth something in the vicinity of ls. 3d., instead of its normal value of approximately 2s. sterling.

talk.start.para: - It has been down to ls. 2d. sterling.

- The devaluing of the yen has been the means of attracting a tremendous amount of foreign trade to Japan. During the last few weeks I have passed through several foreign countries and some towns in which there is practically free trade. In Port Said, Aden and Colombo, I found that practically all the goods sold were of Japanese manufacture, and that the prices were so ridiculously low that trade with other countries had practically ceased. This is likely to continue so long as Japan or any other country obtains trade by the artificial means of manipulating its currency. I also had the privilege of attending an important international conference held in Rome early in April of this year, at which many of the subjects mentioned in the agenda were discussed. The decisions reached at that conference, which consisted of delegates from 28 countries, were sent on for further discussion at the British Economic Conference now being held in London. At the conference in Rome it was found that customs barriers, and, in fact, all barriers to international trade, constituted a difficult problem. It was rather peculiar to hear the views expressed 'by some of the delegates as to what they considered the right way in which to obtain some benefit or improvement in world conditions. They all had the same idea of getting as much as they could, and of giving away as little as possible. I am very much afraid that we shall find a similar policy adopted at the World Economic Conference now being hold in London. It will be practically impossible to reach an agreement on many vital questions, owing to the fact that all countries, with, perhaps, the exception of Great Britain, who is prepared to place all her cards on the table, will adopt the attitude that they are entitled to get as much as they can. I fail to see how it will be possible to reach an agreement on many of the subjects to be dealt with at that conference. In quoting further from this document, I shall confine myself to the manipulation or stabilization of the exchange, as the other points which I intended to mention with regard to tariff barriers have already been ably dealt with by Senator Millen. On page 21 of the report, it is stated that-

quote.para: Thus,- exchange restrictions, and clearing agreements which often follow, constitute an almost .insurmountable obstacle to the circulation of capital, and represent one of the main causes of the falling off in international trade. A return to normal conditions presupposes their disappearance, which is itself conditional, in each of the countries concerned, on the permanent restoration of equilibrium in the balance of payments.

speech.para: On page 23 the following appears: -

quote.para: Restrictions on international trade, whether they take the form of prohibitions or of quotas or licences, have in recent years become exceptionally widespread, and are so numerous that they now constitute an almost insurmountable barrier to international exchanges. They have brought about an unprecedented reduction in international trade, and threaten it with complete paralysis.

speech.para: This document has been prepared by a committee of international experts,' representing different countries whose names have already been quoted. This is a matter which concerns, not only the British Empire, but the whole world. On page 25 the report states that -

quote.para: During the last few years, the situation has been aggravated by the existence, side by side with the system of trade restrictions, of various measures of foreign exchange control. These 'measures fall essentially within the monetary and financial sphere. But in practically all cases they constitute one of the most serious impediments to the exchange of goods, by restricting international payments. Exchange restrictions have also led to the adoption of a large number of clearing, compensation, and barter agreements, and the like. The object of such agreements originally was to enable trade to continue in spite of the restrictions in force; but they have since been given a wider application. Sometimes they operate so as to divert trade into artificial channels, to give artificial advantages to producers in the countries employing them, and to involve discrimination in the discharge of accumulated and current debts, as between creditors of different nationalities. These clearings and compensation agreements have a particularly disruptive influence owing to their tendency to give a purely bilateral character to international commercial and financial relations, and they should be promptly abandoned if normal conditions are to be restored.

speech.para: The advice seems to be that if 'at all possible there should be a more extensive flow of international trade, which during recent years has been severely restricted. In this connexion, we have noticed that every country is endeavouring, as far as possible, to keep trade within its own boundaries. Even the small European countries, which a few years ago had to import practically the whole of their foodstuffs, are now nearly self supporting. I allude, for instance, to Italy, a country which I had the privilege of visiting a short time ago. Until recently, Italy had to import practically all the wheat required to feed the Italian people, but at present every little block of land throughout Italy is being cultivated to the utmost extent, and that country, in the matter of foodstuffs, is now almost self contained.

talk.start.para: - Would the honorable senator suggest that that production be discontinued?

- No, but perhaps with a larger measure of international trade we could take more from Italy of the products she manufactures, and Italy in return could purchase from Australia those commodities which we can produce more economically. I also noticed to my surprise that rice is being produced in Italy. I believe that the Italian people are growing enormous quantities, and I believe economically.
- In Lombardy?

- Rice is being grown in Lombardy and in Picardy. It is being produced on small blocks by means of intense cultivation, as in Eastern countries. It will therefore be seen that, to a certain extent, Italy is becoming self supporting in regard to those commodities essential to the people. We have to consider the cost of production, and the capacity of the world to consume. After all, the fact remains that the prices of certain commodities have been so low that it has been impossible for the producers to purchase to the same extent they did a few years ago. If it is possible to raise price levels to the point at which they stood a few years ago, say in 1929, we should do it, for that would increase the purchasing power of the people, and enable them to buy larger quantities of goods. This would, undoubtedly, help the people on the land, as well as those in the cities.

speech.para: I am in general agreement with the tariff policy of the Government, but, naturally, I reserve to myself the right to criticize certain items, and to vote against them if I think it necessary. I should like to see some of the duties reduced, especially those applicable to articles needed by the primary producers. As our primary producers must sell their products on the markets of the world at world prices, we should make the goods they must buy available to them at the lowest possible price. I shall support the motion for the second reading of the bill.

talk.start.para: . - I wish to discuss certain statements made by the Minister in charge of the bill (Senator McLachlan), which seem, so far, to have escaped the attention of honorable senators. I have had passages with Senator McLachlan on various occasions, but I congratulate him upon the excellent second-reading speech which he delivered. As he said, the tariff is one of the most important subjects which we could discuss in existing circumstances, and we should do everything possible to deal with it in such a way as to relieve the existing economic strain. The Minister, and also Senator Millen, stated that tariff barriers which caused too strong an emphasis to be placed on economic nationalism were one of the main causes of the difficulty which the world is now facing. I contended in the speech which I delivered on the motion for the first reading of this bill, that our greatest trouble originated long before France began the depreciated currency race. It began when the bondholders, whose activities are centred principally in New York and London, commenced a deliberate squeeze with the object of bringing about a higher return or favorable re-adjustment in regard to the huge amount of interest payable on the thousands of millions of pounds invested in loans to other countries. The second main cause of our troubles - there are, of course, contributory causes - was the cessation of lending by the creditor countries.
- Is not the root cause the war ?

- It was one of the main causes, because it increased the debts of many nations, and so increased the interest bill. The war undoubtedly caused a revolutionary change in the position of many nations, and converted some debtor nations into creditor nations. It has been said, with truth, that while it took Great Britain 100 years to accumulate a credit of £4,000,000,000 in her world trade, it took the United States of America perhaps fifteen years to convert her debt of £2,000,000,000 into a credit of £4,000,000,000. In other words, in the short period of fifteen years or so, the United States of America was changed from a heavy debtor nation into a strong creditor nation. There are, of course, other creditor nations, like France; but iri consequence of the wai", the financial authorities of the United States of America took the box seat, and became a leader in a race for financial supremacy. At present the United States of America is actually in the position of a world dictator on finance. Undoubtedly New York and London control the position. This view is supported by men of such standing as Professor Walter Murdoch, who, in a recent address to the members of the Perth Rotary Club on " The Art of Swindling ", declared that the basic swindle of our time and the cause of the present distress was the banking system, which could create and destroy money at the will of a, small group of men who had become the irresponsible lords of the world.

speech.para: Professor Murdoch is a respectable and honoured citizen. He is uncle of a much younger man who was honoured with a knighthood early -this month. Professor Murdoch is not an economist, but a literary authority of undisputed ability. In the course of his address, he quoted from a leading article of the London Times, to the effect that the economic experts had expressed so many conflicting opinions and had given such contradictory advice that it seemed to bc time to turn to men not professing to be experts and consequently unhampered by preconceived theories.

Some honorable senators opposite seem to think that we should offer worship at the feet of the so-called economists of the present day; but I disagree with that view. The mere fact that a man has won the degree of bachelor of the science of economics or has proceeded even to the degree of doctor of that science, is not a sufficient reason for accepting his statements holus bolus. We all know that many of the economists of the 19th century who, in their day, were regarded as outstanding leaders, lived long enough to see their pet theories discredited. Some of them swallowed their most dogmatic utterances. John Stuart Mill, as we all know, became practically a socialist. There is no reason, therefore, why we should accept without question even the words of the economists who prepared the annotated agenda for the World Economic Conference from which the Minister in charge of this bill quoted at' considerable length.

talk.start.para: - To whom docs the honorable senator think we should look for advice?
- We should look to those who have passed through the mill of practical experience. They are often able to give a better reading than university professors, who deal in theory and not practice.
- W - We should certainly apply our %own common sense to the advice that the economists give us.

- That is so. Experience is the best teacher. I do not want to deal with extraneous subjects, but I must say that I have been amused to read some of the comments on the happenings at the recent test matches between England and Australia, by persons who did not see the matches. Those who played the game and saw it played know very well what happened; and they also know the effect of body-line bowling. So I suggest that those who pass through the mill of practical experience in our financial and economic world know exactly what is happening. At present, a veil hides from the general public the happenings in the banking parlours of the world. With all due respect to those who prepared the annotated agenda for the World Economic Conference, I say that we shall not solve the [problems which confront us unless we bring practical experience to the consideration of them. That is the point that Professor Murdoch made in the address which he delivered. I hope I shall not be charged with seeking to curry favour with the Government when I repeat that, in my opinion, the Minister in charge of this bill delivered an excellent address in moving the motion for the second reading of the measure; ho gave us much information and thoughtful comment on the various solutions offered for the removal of the present world disaster. No one, of course, will agree with all that he said, for no two senators will think exactly alike on those subjects. I shall quote, briefly, extracts from the Minister's speech on which I wish to enlarge. The honorable gentleman, in dealing with debtor and creditor nations, said -

quote.para: It may perhaps be said that the foundations are now being laid upon which, ultimately, some new superstructure may be erected by the forcible and even temporarily disastrous process of levelling the too great inequalities between debtor and creditor nations. The surpluses of the creditor nations arc being destroyed; the debtors are, by default, by accommodation with their creditors, or by a reduction of imports, striving to bridge the gap in their debit balances.

talk.start.para: - The experience of the United States of America affords a good illustration of the destruction of the surpluses of creditor nations.

- That country so managed its currency as to help it to get upon its feet again, and is still quite strong enough to get along without outside assistance, but there is no doubt that the debtor nations are suffering. When that policy was put into operation, the people of the United States of America necessarily suffered, too, and the effect of the policy was felt throughout the world. When creditor nations ceased to lend, development was arrested, and world industry was almost brought to a standstill. A few years before the world crisis came to a head - about the end of 1928, or the beginning of 1929 - about £150,000,000 was being lent annually to other nations by the United States of America, and when that stream of capital ceased to flow, the effect on development was tremendous. A whisper went through the banking" parlours that development was not to be undertaken ; in other words, that deflation was to take place. Proof of this is found in the fact that Australia was unable to borrow from Great Britain, although plenty of money was available there. The private banks in England are bursting with it, and they have earned large dividends in recent years, even as high as 18 per cent. That, I maintain, is one of the reasons why the nations have been forced by deflation into the fierce battle of raising tariffs, one against the other. While the Minister's statement admits the lending policies of the great creditor nations as one of the considerations to be discussed, it proceeds as follows : -

quote.para: There is no way of escape by lending more money to nations already too deeply in debt - like individuals, they must live within their means - but in the urgent necessity for- finding this new equilibrium, all nations have been forced to accept a lower standard.

speech.para: I shall make one quotation from The Sydney Sun and Guardian, of the 4th June, 1933. The financial editor of that newspaper, Mr. W. J. Jackson, states, as the Minister rightly said, that the origin of the world trouble is mainly the war. He remarks -

quote.para: The origin of the world's present troubles is the war. The original trouble has spread like cancer until each branch - tariffs, quota, prohibition, lending policy, debts and currency - is quite capable of killing the world economic body.

speech.para: This writer emphasizes the importance of the lending policy, but I place it second only to the deflation order that was sent throughout the world by those who control the credit system. Mr. Jackson goes on to speak of the " erratic " currencies of the world, but I do not wish to deal now with that matter. The Minister further stated -

quote.para: Democracies like short cuts and simple remedies. It is comforting to them to believe that the disasters that have overtaken the world are the inevitable outcome of private enterprise, rather than of war and its aftermath, and that the path to recovery is through a wider and wider extension of governmental and other bureaucratic activities!

speech.para: Was not the war the result of private enterprise?One of the suggestions of Mr. Davidson, the general manager of the Bank of New South Wales, in his latest circular, was a recommendation that one way out of the trouble was investment of money in public works. He considered that the time was ripe for the consideration of this matter as one means of assisting to overcome the present internal difficulty.

talk.start.para: - Did he mention the particular activities that should be proceeded with?
- No.
- None of them does.

- But those who have read Mr. Davidson's circular know that the suggestion did not originate with him. I think that he said that an extensive public works policy would provide a means of getting money iinto circulation. During the debate in this chamber last year, I suggested that we should control our internal loans and our internal currency to the extent of launching a big programme of public works, and I mentioned such proposals as the unification of railway gauges, which was estimated to cost £57,000,000, the construction of a railway from Queensland to the Northern Territory - this has since been supported by a private syndicate, who asked the Federal Government to give them the right to build such a line - and also harbour improvements. I do not suggest for a moment that I have exhausted the list of works that could be profitably undertaken. Various suggestions have been made to me since, such as land-settlement propositions, which are excellent in their way. I was much amused, on reading the Canberra Times, when an honorable member in another place spoke on the subject of the need for uniformity of railway gauges in Australia, which I had suggested as a necessary public work which would provide a means of useful employment, that this was regarded by that journal as a new constructive suggestion. The writer was, apparently, unaware that I had mentioned that matter and other constructive proposals for our present troubles in this chamber. We should take a hand in the matter of assisting internal recovery, as Mr. David son remarked, by government investment. That gentleman may not be in agreement with the Labour party as to the best means of giving effect to that policy ; but, if the Government of the day would adopt an extensive public works policy, it would ease the position in Australia to a large extent, and indicate to the World Economic Conference that Australia, at any rate, considers that the policy of deflation, which has been practised for the last three or four years, should come to an end. Further on, the Minister said-

quote.para: The true escape lies in an increase of prices, in a solution of the short-term debt problem, and in the adjustment, where necessary, of the long-term indebtedness.

speech.para: An increase of prices connotes inflation. The Scullin Government proposed an internal loan, or, if money could be obtained at the old rates, the borrowing of it from creditor countries such as Britain and the United States of America. The fact seems inescapable that we must have an increase of prices, for otherwise we shall continue for a long time to suffer the terrific injustice of paying interest on our war debt at rates which would make it necessary to produce two bushels of wheat where one was previously sufficient to meet our liability. Undoubtedly, some adjustment of our long term indebtedness is required.
The Minister's statement includes the assertion -

quote.para: Exchangecontrol cannot be withdrawn before the return of confidence, and confidence waits on the withdrawal of exchange control.

speech.para: I ask the Minister, who destroyed confidence? He cannot blame the workers or the producers for that, and I do not imagine that he will blame any section of the Australian people, not even the secessionists of Western Australia. I regard the secession movement in that State as an evil manifestation of the process of deflation which was begun at the other end of the world. I regard Senator Johnston as a true Australian first, and as an imperialist afterwards, but, owing to the world trouble, like his State, overwrought. The Minister said a little later -

quote.para: It is generally conceded by students of economics that one of the principal causes of the continued deadlock in the world depression is the discrepancies between costs and selling prices. Opinions differ as to the host means of breaking this deadlock. Two alternative lines of policy, in particular, are being widely discussed.

speech.para: So far as the discrepancy between costs and selling prices is concerned, the workers have received their share of the kicks due to the reduction of costs, for their wages have gone down by at least 30 per cent., even where they have been in constant work, while those who have been unemployed have suffered frightfully. They have lost their homes, and any savings that they may have accumulated. Personally, I have had the bitter experience of suffering loss on account of the present depression. Undoubtedly, the workers have had more than their share of the misfortunes consequent upon it. I believe that the problem is capable of solution ; but those who control the financial situation will not be satisfied until the workers' standard of living is so depressed that the workers are carrying the whole burden of the £40,000,000 of war costs.
The Minister then dealt with other measures that he considers should! bt adopted in order to restore equilibrium.

The decline in commodities prices, due to the policy of deflation that has become general throughout the world, has been directly responsible for an enormous increase of unemployment in all countries, and ha3 imposed on the working classes a burden heavier than that on any other section of the community. The Minister went on to say -

quote.para: At the moment there is little sign of any agreement upon a single heroic effort- -

speech.para: I like that word " heroic " ! - either to raise the average price level, or to scale down costs.

While prices for commodities were high, and while creditor nations, such as England and the United States of America, continued the export of capital, Australia, in common with other debtor countries, was able to carry the load of world debt without, perhaps, undue effort. But, in recent years, there has been- a remarkable change in the situation, duc to the adoption of the policy of deflation. Doubtless, it will be within the memory of even Senator Hardy, who, I understand, first undertook the serious study of politics in 1929, and, I may add, is making a very good fist of it, that there was a boom in prices for several years after the war. It is true that there was a slight recession in 1921-22; but, generally speaking, the world appeared to be in a prosperous condition until about 1928, when those controlling the "money power, to bring about a certain result, conceived the grand scheme of depressing prices and checking the flow of credit. It is thus apparent that the war was not the immediate cause of the widespread depression.

talk.start.para: - It would have been better if all nations had shortened sail immediately after the war.

- -I agree with the Minister that nations, like individuals when they incurred debts, should then have shortened sail; in other words, they should have cut unnecessary expenditure in order to discharge their obligations. That happens to be my position at the present time. But the nations did not take that course. Instead, they continued their wild career of lavish expenditure, believing, doubtless, that the good times would last indefinitely, and it is true to say that, for a number of years after the war, certain sections of the people in every country had a very good time. Now all nations have to face the realities of the situation, and make up their minds what they were going to do about it.

speech.para: In the controlling of world monetary policies, governments have not nearly so much power as they are popularly supposed to possess. Were it otherwise, I should be inclined ' to berate the Government more fiercely than I have hitherto attempted to do in this chamber. We are all, more or less, agents for particular forces, and, when things go wrong, governments, like individuals, have not that full power to right them which many people suppose that they have. Despite the heavy debts incurred by all countries during the war, financial difficulties did not appear to be imminent until 1928, when those in control of the money power began to restrict credit, throughout the world. What happened in Australia was part of the general scheme. It has been suggested tha_t this country, which appeared to be the most prosperous of the nations about that time, was the first to' feel the shock of this changed monetary policy, when those who were responsible for it thought, probably, that their interests would 'best be served by a. deflationary movement, which would have the effect of depressing commodities prices and wage standards. The Minister went on to say -

quote.para: But -the probability becomes clearer that there will.be no single panacea.

speech.para: As on the field of battle, so in times of peace,- when grave difficulties confront a country, many causes, other than strategic skill, may be responsible for victory or defeat. It seems clear, on all the evidence) that the relaxing of the grip of world money power on world industry, arid' the continuing of credit by the only nations that can give it, would at least be a very substantial step towards bringing the world back to the position it occupied a few years ago.

The Minister quoted at some length from 'the annotated agenda of the World Economic Conference, prepared by a body described ' as a preparatory commission of' experts'." I am hopeful that the pressure of the bondholders and the money power' against 'governments will soon be relieved./' If it is not, complete disaster is ahead for all countries. Australia cannot for much longer continue with its present army of approximately 400,000 unemployed persons. Every father of a son who is out of work knows how serious is this menace. The young people of this country are being ruined through the lack of employment in the most formative period of their lives. I heard recently that one nursing institution had received hundreds of applications from young women for the few positions that were vacant. The same thing is happening in practically every industry in this country. On every hand the surplus of labour is enormous, and since the vast majority of the unemployed are young people, they are not having a fair chance at the starting point of their lives. The Minister, referring to the work ahead of the World Economic Conference, quoted the following from the annotated agenda : -

quote.para: In essence, the necessary programme is one nf economic disarmament.

speech.para: Economic armaments in all countries have been rapidly increasing, because of the stoppage of credit and export of capital, with the resultant damping down of prices. Even in this partly developed country we had to prohibit the importation of many commodities to prevent complete disaster. The Scullin Government, which imposed embargoes and raised the tariff on many items, had this objective in mind. Had there been in power a freetrade government like the Bruce-Page Administration, it would not have given effect to a legislative programme necessary to save Australia. At that critical period of our history the need was, not for protection in the case of any particular tariff item, but for the actual prohibition of importations of many commodities in order to prevent the country from becoming bankrupt.
The annotated agenda emphasizes the importance of the greater creditor nations of the world. Dealing with tariff reform, the committee which prepared the agenda states -

quote.para: Positive action in this direction is assured of important support. Countries compelled to dispose of a large proportion of their products, whether agricultural or industrial, on the world markets are most deeply interested in checking the increase of tariff barriers, and in securing their reduction.

An improvement in the world economic situation would be facilitated if the debtor countries were enabled to pay their debts by the export of goods and services, and if the creditor countries framed their economic policy in such a way as to maintain the capacity of debtor countries to pay by these means. These creditor countries can expect to collect interest and principal only if they so adjust their financial and commercial policies as to make payment by the debtors possible.

speech.para: This the creditor nations have not clone. They have practically a mortgage of enormous dimensions on debtor countries. If the world is to recover, they must undoubtedly release their grip, and modify their lending and commercial policies. They should give the " Word " - investing it with the full scriptural significance - to their agents throughout the world to ease the onerous conditions that lie so heavily on debtor nations. No one will deny that this monetary dominion is exercised mainly by financial interests in New York and London. Homer Lee, in his well-known book, The Day of Hie Saxon, published some years before the war, pointed out that, because of his ruling world position, the Anglo-Saxon of New York and London controlled the destinies of the world. The Slav danger and the Teutonic menace are now in the background. The day of the Anglo-Saxon has arrived, and all the evidence goes to show that his exercise of the money power must be tempered with discretion, because, if used unwisely, it will bring ruin, not only to the world generally, but also to those who abuse their power.
Dealing with tariff policies, the committee which prepared the annotated agenda states -

quote.para: Tariff policy can obviously not be dealt with in isolation. An effective and lasting return to greater freedom of trade cannot be looked for unless -it is accompanied by a general and durable improvement in financial and monetary conditions, any more than a permanent improvement of the financial and monetary situation can be looked for so long as international trade is not freed from it3 chief obstacles.

speech.para: I have not seen the complete copy of the annotated agenda, so I depend for my information upon the long quotations made from it by the Minister in his speech the other night. I am glad to note that it emphasizes the responsibility resting on the great" creditor nations, which, for some years, have been in the world's financial saddle. To bring about an improvement, we must first have a definite alteration of world financial policy. Those in control of it are comparatively few. Probably half a dozen persons, at the most, use this enormous power of deflation throughout the world with its attendant miseries for so many millions of people. Every year, the .advance of science brings the world closer together. It now takes no longer to travel from London to Australia or from Australia to New York than it took to go from Edinburgh to London one hundred years ago. Economically, as well as geographically, the world is being brought together, though racially and linguistically its countries may still be far apart. It is some satisfaction to me to see in this annotated agenda some of the things which I have emphasized in former speeches. Any one who takes the trouble to study the facts and the indiscreet remarks of various important persons from time to time, must realize that the present position of the world has been brought about by a vast organization of capital on the other side of the world. The total population of Australia is not greater than that of some of the English counties. Despite its size, Australia is not so important to the world as is the State of New York in the United States of America - a State that, alone, has over 10,000,000 people.

The remarks of Senator DuncanHughes regarding the British Empire were interesting. Australia is a part of that Empire; but what would have been its position had the Great War destroyed the Empire? This country must seek protection outside its borders; and if that protection 'were not forthcoming from the source to which we have looked for it in the past, we should probably have sought it from the United States of America. Australia owes a great debt to the Empire to which it belongs, and, because of that, the people of this country are inclined to swallow without question the policy of Britain. Australia is a grown-up nation, and it should say definitely to the Motherland and to the United States of America that their domination has continued long enough. Although a strong protectionist, I should like to see international freetrade throughout the world, so long as it was properly controlled. The adoption of such a policy would solve the world's troubles, and avert a war every hundred years or so. In dealing with the tariff schedule, I shall do my best to protect Australian industries, with a view to making Australia as self-contained as possible; but I hope that the World Economic Conference now sitting in London will do something for the benefit of humanity in general, so that the workers and producers throughout the world will no longer be ground down by the money forces which now dominate all nations.

talk.start.para: . - This tariff debate is not different from other tariff debates to which I have listened. Whenever a tariff schedule is before the Senate, those who believe in the highest form of protection describe as freetraders who are out to smash Australian industries those who advocate a moderate tariff. Unfortunately, that cry is repeated in a large section of the press of Australia. That accusation is generally directed against the members of the Country party, which is said to be "the most' one-eyed' section in the community,which wants everything possible for itself, but is unwilling to allow other sections of the community any privilege whatever." That that view is not held by all the people of Australia is evident from the fact that this Parliament contains a member of Country party members. In my opinion, there is no such person as a hundred-per-cent. protectionist. Every protectionist whom I have known believes in the highest possible protection for the particular industry in which he is engaged, and in absolute freetrade in the raw materials which he uses Australian manufacturers of cloth would not hesitate to buy their wool outside Australia, if they could get wool of equal quality at a lower price. Yet they howl to high Heaven, and to this Parliament, to protect them against their brethren in England from whom, as it were, they obtained their mother's milk.
- That is true of everybody.

- At the moment I am speaking of protectionists. I hope that in this matter I am as impartial as is any other man. The cloth manufactured in the Australian factory goes to the tailor, or to the manufacturer of ready-made clothing, who, in turn, appeals to this Parliament to provide him with cloth free of duty for manufacture by him into clothing, while, at the same time, he asks that the highest duty possible shall be placed on made-up garments imported from other countries. And so the process continues. I have yet to meet a man who genuinely believes in the principle of protection all round. Like the pious editor of whom James Russell Lowell wrote -

quote.para: I don't believe in princerple
But, oh, Idu in interest.

talk.start.para: - I know a man who is a one-hundred-per-cent. protectionist.
- The honorable senator would make a fortune if he exhibited that man throughout the country. The people would like to see him.

speech.para: SenatorCollings. - No one would dare to show a one-hundred-per-cent. freetrader in Australia.

talk.start.para: - Senator Crawford gave a novel and extraordinary reason for the inclusion in the Federal Constitution of the sliding scale by which Western Australia was to benefit for five years. The honorable senator said that that provision was inserted in the Constitution in order to enable Western Australia to establish its own industries, so that that State would not be at the mercy of the eastern States. Senator Crawford is, I think, the first man to offer that explanation.
- I have been first in many things.

- Unfortunately, the man who is first is not always right. If Senator Crawford will cast his mind back to the time of the framing of the Constitution, he will realize that Western Australia with a handful of people, had a man-sized job on hand. It is to the credit of that State that, instead of giving up the task, it accomplished so much.

speech.para: Senator Rae said that the people in the country should not run away with the idea that a high tariff benefited only the people in the cities. I shall not ask Senator Rae to accept the word of a " semi-freetrader," as I am described, on this subject, but shall read what was said by Sir Henry Gullett when he was Minister for Trade and Customs on the occasion when he introduced the Ottawa agreement in another place. I say quite openly that on whatever other matter Sir Henry and I may disagree, I am in hearty accord with this statement.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator is quoting Sir Henry Gullett with approval?
- Yes, because I believe that his utterances on this occasion were honest and sincere. Sir Henry Gullett said : -

quote.para: The agreement will benefitall sorts and conditions of people, and it will make stronger both the Commonwealth and the United Kingdom in a collective sense. That which makes Australia stronger in a general sense and adds in a general way to the strengthof Britain must commend itself to this House, and to the Australian people. But the Australian Delegation, with the full support of the Commonwealth Government, aimed for something nearer and more tangible than a general benefit either to Australia or to the United Kingdom., From the beginning of the preparation for Ottawa until the conference closed, we worked for benefits for our primary producers.

We worked in the belief that in the fashioning of tariff in this- country the man on the land, and his employees, have 'hitherto come off second best. They have been given, it is true, compensatory duties and arrangements in an endeavour to balance them up, and, with respect to the local Australian market, that policy has been attended by some success.
It will be noticed that Sir Henry does not say that the policy has been attended with complete success. He goes on -

But with respect to the great export surplus of primary production the man on the land and those who work for him have been, to state it mildly, somewhat overlooked by this Parliament. It is scarcely an exaggeration^ to say that, hitherto, this Parliament has been in tariff and industrial legislation a twostandard Parliament - a standard for the cities and another standard, very much inferior, for the country.

This Ottawa agreement, which I now submit to the House, makes an attempt, belated it is true, but a sincere, constructive and comprehensive attempt to adjust that unfair balance. It proclaims in the first place the inherent right of the country people of Australia and their industries to equal economic consideration with the city people and secondary industries in this Parliament. Next it recognizes the desperate plight of all who are engaged in primary industry at the present time, and their imperative claims to assistance and relief. It is an acknowledgment, too. of the plain, unchallengeable truth, that had it not been for the magnificent fortitude and industry of our farmers and pastoralists, and their unprecedented production and export during these years of adversity, there must have been a total collapse of our whole financial and industrial structure, with a calamitous further increase of unemployment and money available neither for its relief nor for the maintenance of our great social services.
