We owe our financial, industrial and economic salvation during this crisis to the man on the land. This agreement has been drawn in aid of the man on the land, but it has the supreme merit that, if we aid the man on the land, we aid every agency of industry and business, and employment in the Commonwealth. This charter of rural aid could be a thousand times justified if it carried in it the curbing of other Australian interests to the advantage of primary industry.

speech.para: And then he adds - but does not reduce the protective level of our Australian tariff.

That is the considered opinion of one of the leaders of protectionist thought in Australia, and I commend it to the attention of those honorable senators who say that the man on the land is getting all the plums, while the unfortunate worker in the city is being ground to death by the producer.

talk.start.para: - "Who said that'?

- It has been plainly and openly said in this chamber. A good many honorable senators have quoted from the Ottawa trade agreement in an endeavour to prove that it confers no benefit on Australia, but makes many ^concessions to Great Britain. I have not heard any honorable senator who holds such opinions .quote article 4, which reads -

quote.para: His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom undertake that the general ad valorem duty of ten per cent., imposed by section 1 of the Import Duties Act 1932, on the foreign goods specified in schedule D shall not be reduced except with the consent of His Majesty's Government in the Commonwealth of Australia.

speech.para: I should like to ask whether, in any part of the Ottawa agreement, Australia has given the British Government the right to ask whether we shall or shall not impose a duty on any article.

talk.start.para: - No ; we have left that to the Tariff Board.

- I remember that when Senator Crawford was Assistant Minister for Trade and Customs he was one of the warmest admirers and supporters of the Tariff Board. I do not know what has occurred to cause that body to fall from grace in his estimation. I assure honorable senators, if such an assurance is now necessary, that the Country party does not believe in- absolute freetrade. Belief in a revenue tariff is one of the planks in the platform of the Western Australian association to which I belong. A tremendous amount of duty may be collected under a revenue tariff, and some of the duties imposed for the purpose should be high enough to please anybody. What we object to is an excessive tariff which places a burden upon the rest of the community. Some honorable senators will claim that there are no excessive duties, and that no exploitation of the community is taking place. To enlighten them I shall read a report which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of the 1st June last, of a case which was heard in the Arbitration Court in Melbourne. It is as follows: -

quote.para: Arthur W. Briggs, secretary of Yarra Falls Limited, Abbotsford, which employs 1,200 hands, said, in evidence, that a reduction of hours to 44 a week would increase wages and overhead costs by from 0 per cent, to 8i per cent.

Mr. Sheehan. Your company last year made ?30,000 profit from other investments. Has it ?25,000 invested in the Globe Worsted Mills, ?50,000 in Julias Kayser Proprietary Limited, ?50,000 in Australian Knitting Mills Limited, and ?25,000 in Australian Silks and Cotton?

subdebate.1.para: Were those investments made from accumulated funds?- Partly.

I suggest that that word " partly " means 99 per cent. If that is not an excessive profit to be made by an industry that is enjoying great benefit as a result of our protective tariff, I should like a precise definition of the word " excessive ".

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator has never objected to the excessive profits which have been made by foreign companies trading with Australia.

- Our only control over foreign exploiters trading with the Australian public is through the medium of the Industries Preservation Act, whose sections the Minister may bring into force without consulting Parliament by imposing a heavy dumping duty on the goods which those exploiters are landing in this country to the detriment of our manufacturers.
- W - What was the original capital of the company to which the honorable senator has referred?
- I have no idea. That has nothing to do with the case. I am speaking of surplus profits that have been invested in other companies after the parent concern had paid a dividend of S? per cent.
- The honorable senator has never objected to the profits that were made by the BritishImperial Tobacco Company. *

- I have already stated that I object to excessive profits and the exploitation of the people by any company, whether it be the BritishImperial Tobacco Company or any other concern, and I do not retract one word of that statement. I am prepared to give a fair and reasonable tariff protection to any industry that is of benefit to Australia.

speech.para: Objection has been taken to article 9 of the Ottawa agreement, which reads -

quote.para: His Majesty's Government in the Commonwealth of Australia undertake that protection by tariffs shall be afforded only to those industries which are reasonably assured of sound opportunities for success.

speech.para: Surely no reasonably-minded person can object to that! Would any honorable senator advocate that protection should be lavished upon 'a number of abortive industries which have no chance of success, merely as a means of squandering public money ? Anybody who knows anything about farming and pastoral pursuits is aware that a farmer will not rear a defective animal that has no hope of developing into a useful beast, but will knock it on the head, and thus save futile expense. According to those who object to article 9, we should rear and spoonfeed defective industries which, because they are cripples, want more coddling than does a healthy organization.

talk.start.para: - Not at all. That clause is an insult to our common sense.

- It is plain that those who drew up the agreement on behalf of Australia and Great Britain were aware that, in the past, indiscriminate protection has been lavished on good and bad alike, and that many industries, which could not possibly give a return on the money invested, have taken heavy toll from the people of Australia. As a further instance of the way in which the primary industries have been dealt with, I shall quote from a report of the Tariff Board on butter and cheese, which was issued on the 28th of November, 1927 -

quote.para: The whole of the evidence tended to show that the butter industry is in a stagnant and unpayable condition, and without exception, witness after witness described the lot of the dairy farmer as a constant struggle to make ends meet, and that it was only possible to continue in the industry by utilizing the labour of the wife and family of the dairyman and working unduly long hours. Whore labour is employed it is undoubted that it is paid extremely low wages, and even under the above conditions, it was maintained on all sides that the dairy farm hardly paid its way and did not give anything like a fair and adequate return to the dairy farmer.

talk.start.para: - The price of butter was then higher than it is to-day.
- It was considerably higher. The report goes on to say-

quote.para: After hearing .the evidence, the Tariff Board has arrived at the conclusion that the dairying industry in Australia ' is being carried on under conditions involving long hours to the dairy farmer; that in very many cases the farmers are utilizing the services of the women and children of the family, and that when labour is employed it is receiving an extremely low remuneration, and that even under these conditions the farmer himself is not receiving an adequate return either in wages to himself or interest on his capital.

speech.para: It is useless for any one to say that customs duties have not been increased. It is too painfully evident to all that a small reduction of the duties on tools of trade and the machinery necessary for the production of wheat do not adequately offset the lowering of the price of that commodity by at least 75 per cent. Had the reduction of duties been commensurate with the decline in the return to the wheat-grower, a different story would have been told by Australian manufacturers. This country cannot be righted by inflicting an injustice upon one section, to the advantage of another. Any action must benefit the whole of the community. If the purchasing power of the people is lessened, costs must be reduced correspondingly.

I wish to correct the impression in the minds of our friends .opposite, that the primary producer is dependent for a market upon the workers in secondary industries in the cities. The exact opposite is the case. I have nothing to say in disparagement of the home market, which is good so far as it goes; but it falls far short of the requirements of the primary producers of this country. I would remind our friends that the primary producer has the choice of two markets; that he may export what bo cannot sell locally; but that the secondary manufacturer is limited to the local market, and would be in a bad way if it did not absorb the whole of his production, because, so far, he has shown himself utterly unable to compete on the markets of the world, as the wool and the wheat grower have to do. So I suggest that the Government should do its level best so to fix duties that those upon whom Australia really is dependent shall have a fair chance of working out, not only their own salvation, but also the salvation of the rest of Australia.

talk.start.para: . - Having heard the tariff policy of the present Government expounded during the last eighteen months, and having paid particular attention to the proposals incorporated in the bill now before the Senate, one is forced to the conclusion that on this, as on every important matter, the Government is either incapable of making up its mind, or has no mind to make up. The speeches that have been delivered upon the bill probably furnish the reason for the lack of decision, and the hesitation displayed by the Government. The only vital vote so far taken, and the speeches of government supporters^ - whether they be real or nominal supporters remains to be proved by the success or the failure of the Government to pass this legislation in the form it desires - an indicative of a hopeless confusion of thought. In the old days, when 'great forensic battles on fiscal questions were waged in the Commonwealth Parliament, and in the parliaments of the States before federation was established, there was in variably a distinct division of opinion, one element believing in freetrade, and the other favouring protection. Usually, the freetraders advanced other proposals, which in their opinion were better suited to the development of this country; invariably, they were advocates of land value taxation. To-day, however, the charge which Senator Carroll levelled against the protectionist section of this Parliament, and the advocates of protection in this country - that they are not 100 per cent, protectionists - is pertinent to the honorable senator himself, and to many of his colleagues. They are not 100 per cent, anything; they believe in freetrade, free land, and probably, at the bottom of their hearts, free labour. Their code, in its application to the conditions governing the development of industry, is only slightly different from the slave code. Is it to be wondered at that a Government which depends for its support upon persons with such confused ideas, drawn from a party which produces such a multiplicity of opinions that lead nowhere, should be unable to make up its mind on this or any other important subject?

speech.para: During this debate, and on the motion for the first reading of the bill, the domestic quarrel between the two sections that support the Government has been intruded, and another chapter has been added to the famous controversy that has waxed more or less warm for the last fortnight. At the risk that always accompanies interference with domestic quarrels, I consider it wise that at this juncture some observations should be made from this section of the Senate. What took place during the negotiations between the United Australia party and the United Country party has been confused by the welter of assertions, denials, and counter-denials with which the Senate has been regaled for the last fortnight. The story of the quarrel, and of the attempt to patch up a truce between chose two sections, should be permanently embodied in Hansard. But any one who reads the story, which becomes enlarged with each additional testimony, must be hopelessly bewildered as to what was the basis of the agreement. The other evening, Senator Foll, the Government Whip, read at great length a number of extracts from newspapers, which purported to show what had been said by Senator Hardy, Sir Henry Gullett, and Mr. Latham. The excuse that he offered was that he desired to have those statements permanently incorporated in Hansard. I presume that the honorable senator was present at the famous private deputation, which is now said not . to have been private, that took place before Sir Henry Gullett and the other Commonwealth delegates left Australia for Ottawa. As, I presume, Senator Foll was present at the meeting, it is strange that he did not enlighten the Senate and the public generally about what actually transpired there. It is also strange to observe the silence of other honorable senators on this subject. Why have they not given their version of what transpired, and Sir Henry Gullett's reference to the negotiations which took place prior to the election between the United Australia party and the United Country party? Those negotiations must have some bearing upon the tariff bill which we are now discussing. Honorable senators who belong to the United Australia party say that it was arranged that a certain tariff policy should be adopted, but Senator Carroll arid ex-Senator Colebatch say that the arrangement was totally different. The Government denies that it has committed a breach of faith. Senator Brennan, in his excellent contribution to the debate, defended the Attorney-General (Mr. Latham), Sir Henry Gullett and others, but now we find that the apologists for the Government are shifting their ground. First they said that there was no agreement at all, but when it was clearly shown that an agreement had been entered into, they said that it was not ratified by the parties concerned. When it was shown that the Country party did ratify the agreement, the apologists for the Government replied that it had not been proved that the United Australia party had accepted the agreement.

talk.start.para: - I remind the honorable senator that reference to that agreement has been disallowed previously in this debate.

- I a I am referring incidentally to the agreement, in leading up to another point. I am concerned, not with the negotiations which took place between the two parties supporting the Government, but with what occurred prior to the last election. I am concerned with the position' of the great manufacturing industries of this country, and the deliberate breach of faith on the part of the Government in framing its present tariff policy. That, ,1 think, is relevant to the bill under discussion. What were the people of Australia led to believe would be the tariff policy of this Government? On that subject the Melbourne Age published a pertinent article on the 3rd September, 1932, much about the time when an important schedule,which is incorporated in this bill, was tabled by the Government. That article reads -

quote.para: Anxious misgivings were yesterday expressed on behalf of manufacturers affected by the latest reductions in the tariff, who view with considerable apprehension the prospect of increasing importations of competitive products from overseas and foreign sources, with consequent disastrous increase of unemployment here. The action of the Lyons Government, and its general attitude to the tariff measures taken by its predecessors in office, are being discussed from many angles. Manufacturers trusted implicitly in the assurances of
Messrs. Lyons, Latham and Gullett prior to the December elections, that the party led by Mr. Lyons stood for adequate protection through the tariff for Australian industries.

speech.para: The manufacturers were assured by the present Prime Minister, the Attorney-General, and Sir Henry Gullett that if their party gained office it would . provide adequate tariff protection for Australian industries. The article continues - lu view of the repeated tariff reductions, and the express indications of Ministers that the action already taken represents only a first instalment of a continuous process, with heavy further downward revision of duties, there is now a feeling among manufacturers who trusted these pre-election assurances, that theY have been badly " let down."

That article correctly summarizes the position. Behind the back of the Country party the United Australia par tj' made a promise to the manufacturers of this country in order to win doubtful seats like Maribyrnong, Corio, Ballarat and Batman. But this Government, so soon as it gained office, broke its promise, not only to the Country party, but also to the manufacturers, and to-day, it stands discredited in the eyes of every section of the community. Of course, wc can expect nothing else from a government the members of which belong to the United Australia party. Until the people recognize that no matter what name this party masquerades under, it is still the same old conservative gang
Ave shall continue to have repetitions of these disgraceful episodes in the political life of this country.

talk.start.para: - Can the honorable senator supply instances in which the manufacturing industries have been imperilled because of this Government's tariff policy?
- I s I shall give instances as J proceed with my .speech. Let me quote an extract from the Age of the 5th September, 1932.
- That was before the schedule was introduced.

- No. No. This article was published after one of the most important tariff schedules, now incorporated in this bill, had been introduced into the House of Representatives. As a matter of fact, it was the second or third schedule introduced. The first schedule, which was practically innocuous, provided for several minor amendments and the removal of some of the prohibitions which had been imposed by the previous Government, but not for the 'purpose of protecting Australian industries. The Age, in a leading article, stated -

quote.para: As far as the tariff is concerned, the Lyons Ministry won the election on false pretences. It is true that some of those who are now Ministers spoke mildly of "tariff reform", but .it required these successive schedules to reveal the political treachery veiled by the seemingly innocuous phrase.

speech.para: One of the oldest, and possibly one of the soundest, of the press organizations of this country made that scathing condemnation of the action of the government of the day, and I shall show justification for that statement when the specific items in the schedules are under discussion. One of the worst features of the Government's tariff-making or tariff-breaking policy is the uncertainty of its future intentions. This comprehensive schedule was discussed for weeks in the House of Representatives, but before ' honorable senators have reached the discussion' on the items the Government has stated that, at the committee stage, the Senate will be asked to agree to many tariff- alterations. How long is this uncertainty to exist? How long are the workers in the secondary industries and the manufacturers to be kept in suspense as to whether they are likely to be ruined or not as a result of this Government's tariff policy? Surely the people of this country should know where they stand on tariff matters. A notable example of the lack of decision on the part of the Government was furnished only yesterday, . when, prompted by the refusal of the Government to disclose the nature of the Tariff Board's report on' the protective incidence of primage and exchange, Senator Hardy moved the adjournment of the Senate to enable him to ventilate a grievance.

talk.start.para: - Senator Hardy did not move the adjournment for that purpose, and that would have been known to the honorable senator had he been present in the Senate instead of travelling on the train.

- I - I confess that, owing to the inadequate train arrangements between South Australia and Canberra, I was unable to attend the Senate yesterday, and that my only knowledge of what transpired during the debate was gained from this morning's press. Prom that I formed the opinion that Senator Hardy had threatened to take certain steps if the Government did not climb down from the position that it had taken, and that the Leader of of the Senate (Senator Pearce) said, in effect, "Don't shoot, we will climb down ". In other words, the white flag of surrender was hoisted by the Government, and a promise was made to Senator Hardy and his colleagues that, before the bill was finally passed, the report of the Tariff Board on primage and exchange would be made available to honorable senators so that they might, if they so desired, move further amendments to the tariff. The strange silence observed by honorable senators occupying the ministerial bench shows unmistakably that my conclusions are correct. Although the Government has had the report of the Tariff Board under . consideration for at least three months, it has not yet been able to come to any decision upon it. It is hinted, of course, that after the Government has considered the subject for another month or two it may develop a policy in regard to it. We may then have some more, drastic amendments of the tariff. With such uncertainty, how can it be expected that those engaged in secondary industries will develop their enterprises? Even companies that are prepared to extend the capacity of their plant, increase the number of their employees, and add to the output of Australian manufactured goods, are not likely to do anything of the kind while they are uncertain of the tariff position.

speech.para: Why should exchange be seriously considered in relation to the protective policy of the country? The people of Australia are overwhelmingly protectionist in outlook. They believe that Australian primary and secondary industries should be organized under a well-ordered tariff policy. Their development should proceed along parallel roads. To put it in another way, their development should go hand in hand, for there is undoubtedly an affinity between primary and secondary industries in a country like Australia. Surely we are justified in believing that protection is the permanent policy of this nation ! The exchange rate is a fluctuating quantity which should not influence tariff considerations. In the final analysis is it not a fact that just as the exchange places another rail on the top of our tariff wall, and so helps to prevent the undue importation of foreign goods into Australia, it also automatically increases the prices of primary products in Australia, and so helps to add to the cost of the raw material which the Australian manufacturers use? In my opinion, one condition about balances the other, and this makes it unnecessary for us to consider the exchange in its relation of protection.

A notable feature of this debate has been the absence of adverse criticism of the tariff policy of the Scullin Government. Prior to the last election, the Minister in charge of this bill (Senator McLachlan), the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Pearce) and other honorable gentlemen opposite thundered forth denunciations of the Scullin tariff policy. Extracts from their speeches were cabled overseas, and telegraphed to all parts of Australia. After such a furore then, it is remarkable that there should be such a strange silence now. The fact is, of course, that the Scullin tariff was sound, and that it did what it was designed to do.

talk.start.para: - We have 1,200 fewer factories to-day than we had two years ago.

- S - Statistics are queer material. Classifications are changed from time to time. I remember that on one occasion a certain government in South Australia, which desired to convince the people that the State had progressed under its administration, provided that butcher shops should be reckoned as factories. In consequence, the figures showed that the number of factories as well as the number of employees had increased enormously.
- We have 131,000 fewer persons employed now than when the Scullin Government was in office.
- T - That change has occurred in the last two years, during eighteen months of which the present Government has occupied the treasury bench.
- We are paying £35,000,000 per annum less in wages now than we paid then.

- The The honorable senator's interjections all support my argument. The Scullin tariff policy corrected our adverse trade balance, but in the last eighteen months this Government has been engaged upon a tariffreduction . and industry-wrecking policy which has had the consequences indicated by the honorable senator's interjections. The Scullin tariff policy was intended to effect two main purposes. Duties were imposed in order to protect our secondary industries, so that they should become permanent, and prohibitions and surcharges were imposed to correct an adverse trade balance which, we hoped, would be only temporary. We wished to check the flood of imports which had proceeded almost without interruption while the previous Government was in charge of the affairs of the country. Illuminating figures were quoted bySenator Dooley this afternoon, showing the fluctuation of our exports and imports of merchandise. I wish to examine the position in respect to the balance of trade and the payments against the trade balance. If these two items are considered together, they provide a reliable barometer of national solvency. During the eight years that the Bruce-Page Government was in office, our adverse balance, all items included, was £62,380,000 - that is on the trading side of the ledger, after allowing for the export of gold, bullion, and specie; but in the same period the Commonwealth and State governments became liable to oversea interest payments which totalled £193,445,520. So Australia went to the bad during the eight years of the Bruce Page régime to the extent of £255,825,520. This was the calamitous position which faced the Scullin Government when it assumed office. Immediate steps were taken to correct the position, and in two years the adverse trade balance was converted into a favorable trade balance, all items included, of £65,100,000. Oversea interest payments in the same period totalled £56,000,000. This left a surplus in favour of Australia of £9,100,000. This result was achieved under most disadvantageous circumstances. During the eight years of the Bruce-Page regime the prices of our primary products were relatively high; during the two years of the

speech.para: Scullin régime the prices of all our export commodities, except dried fruits and wine, touched the most disastrously low level ever recorded. In spite of this fact, the Scullin Government rectified the adverse trade balance, and placed Australia in a solvent position. This Government has lifted many of the prohibitions and surcharges imposed by the Scullin Government, and I have no quarrel with it for doing so. Had the Scullin Government remained in office, these imposts would have been lifted immediately they had served their purpose. But this Government has gone much further than that. It has reduced our protective duties to such an extent that our trade balance has been disturbed despite the increase in the price of our export commodities. This increase is, of course, in no way attributable to this Government, but is the result of world conditions, which have been discussed during this debate, and which I do not now propose to describe. Although the national income has increased materially, the tariff policy of this Government has seriously interfered with our favorable trade position. Some interesting figures recently released by our statistical department reveal that, for the ten months from the 1st July, 1931,to the 30th April, 1932, the balance of exports over imports, all items included, was £34,422,000, whereas for the ten months from the 1st July, 1932, to the 30th April, 1933, the favorable balance was £36,193,000. These figures seem to be favorable until we discover that the returns for this year include exports of gold from the gold reserve against our note issue, estimated, in sterling value, at £11,265,636. In other words, a raid has been made on the national savings. Of course, this export of gold cannot be repeated next year. There has, therefore, actually been a serious falling off in Australia's favorable trade balance with the outside world.

talk.start.para: - I d I desire briefly to quote from one more authority to show the dangerous condition into which Australia is drifting in regard to its overseas trade as a result of the policy of the present Government. I have here a report published in the Adelaide

speech.para: Advertiser, of the 30th of May last, contributed by the Business Conditions Committee of the Melbourne University Old Commerce Students' Association. It states -

quote.para: The debit on the balance of payments for the year will therefore be approximately £1,000,000 stg. We have frequently stressed the seriousness of such a position following upon several good seasons.

speech.para: The position is undoubtedly serious. Nature has been kind to Australia during the last three or four years, and prolific production has, to some extent, counteracted the effect of low prices.

I referred earlier to the danger to Australian industry from the dumping of goods in the Australian market by overseas manufacturers. Several countries are making attempts to increase their export trade by depreciating their currency, and granting subsidies On exports. Press reports published during the last month or two have made it clear that in Great Britain steps are being taken to counteract the menace. The Australian Government, however, has evinced no disposition to protect Australian industry.

I have been twitted with refraining from making any reference to the effect of the tariff on primary production. I have no desire to evade the issue, and I am convinced that the detrimental effects on the primary industries which are alleged against a protectionist policy are merely so much political propaganda. In the various States, primary industries have been assisted by the construction of non-paying railways, and non-paying water works. These undertakings are not furnishing sufficient revenue to pay the cost of their construction, and the balance has to be made up by taxation. The manufacturing and working sections of the community are thus paying their fair share towards the assistance and development of the primary industries, but the secondary industries have conferred a more direct benefit on those engaged in primary production by furnishing an increasing market for quantities of primary products. I can never understand the mentality of those alleged representatives of the primary producers who favour a policy which would compel the producers to pay freight on their products to convey them thousands of miles to markets in other countries when, by a properly co-ordinated system of development, we could provide a. market in this country for the greater part of what we produce. In order to show to what extent the establishment of secondary industries has already assisted the primary producers, let me compare conditions as they existed in 1907, when the first real attempt at protection was undertaken, with those which existed in 1930, the last year for which complete statistical data are available. In 1907, Australian primary products to the value of £57,646,000 were consumed in Australia, while in 1930, the value had increased to £138,748,000, an increase of £81,102,000. Prices for primary products were practically the same during both periods, so that it will be seenhow tremendous was the increase of consumption during that time. To whom were those primary products sold? For the most part, they were sold to those employed in Australian manufacturing industries, and no better market could possibly exist. Certainly it is an infinitely better market than that which we supplied under the old free-trade policy of importing our requirements From overseas, and trying to induce the people living in low-wage countries, from which we imported, to purchase our primary products.

During this period, the consumption of dairy and farmyard products, which are of a particular type, increased from £12,720,000 in 1907, to £40,855,000 in 1930. In addition to that, on £9,000,000 worth of butter exported from Australia in 1930, the Australian public paid, in the form of a bounty under the Paterson butter scheme, approximately £2,000,000 to the dairy farmers. These are facts, not the rhetoric used by the members of the Country party to tickle the ears of the voters at election time. The truth is now recognized by every intelligent primary producer in the country, and in these times all primary producers are intelligent men. The old days when the farmer was not educated, is past. We have now to deal with primary producers of a new type. They have been emancipated, largely as a result of the policy inaugurated by Labour governments, which has resulted in the creation of better conditions and better local markets. The old days of moleskins and

German print have gone, as has the time when the farmer went in fear and trembling to the local bank or the local storekeeper, wiping his boots on the mat before entering the august presence. The majority of the farmers in these days realize which fiscal policy is better suited to their interests.

Reference was made by Senator Carroll to the cost of agricultural implements. I am in possession of facts which prove that the tariff has not resulted in increas ing the cost of agricultural implements to the farmers. Why did not the honorable senator quote the price of such implements in freetrade countries, or in those overseas British possessions such as East Africa, where there is freetrade?

talk.start.para: - Why not quote prices which prevailed in 1914?
- I - I propose to quote prices in 1921, and those which prevail under the present tariff. They are as follow: -

speech.para: [Extension of time granted.] It has been said that the products of our secondary industries comprise only 4 per cent. of the total value of our exports. That is not true. A great many commodities classified in the statistical returns as primary products should really come under the heading of manufactured goods. For instance, butter, metals, &c., which have gone through expensive processes in Australia, are just as much secondary products asis the cloth from a woollen mill. I have here a list of about 200 items of this kind, all of which have been processed before export. Their total value is no less than £23,315,484, representing 26 per cent. of the value of our total exports for the year 1930-31. For that year the value of our exports in Australian currency was £89,056,000, of which approximately £65,000,000 represented real primary products. Included in this list is butter, valued at £8,120,165 ; cheese, £244,066; flour, £3,513,573; other cereal manufactures, £419,717 ; preserved fruits, £610,779 ; and lead manufactures, £2,424,808. It is obvious that each of those items has been subjected to an extensive and, in most cases, an expensive manufacturing process before leaving Australia. This shows that Australian industries can be built up under a protective tariff, because these products have to be sold in open competition in the world's markets. "We have the finest lead-smelting works in the world at Port Pirie, in South Australia. These works were established, and have been maintained, under our protective policy. The mines at Iron Knob and Hummocky Hill, in that State, export iron ore in competition with other countries. From £400,000 to £500,000 worth per annum is sent to various parts of the world, and last year substantial consignments were despatched to the United .States of America,- in the teeth of world competition. That disposes of the fallacious argument of the opponents of the protective tariff of this country that only primary products can be exported from Australia under such a policy.

This, Government has already done sufficient harm by the amendments of the Scullin tariff which it has made. "Why allow the doubt which exists in the minds of manufacturers and their employees to-day to continue as the result of statements which come from authoritative sources, and are never corrected by the Government, to the effect that this is only the first instalment of its tariff policy? During the course of this debate, we have heard ample quotations from the agenda of the World Economic Conference, showing that honorable senators are at least aware of the fact that, during the next twelve months,, vast and far-reaching changes in the economic position of the world may be made. While the present possibilities remain, we should pursue a stable fiscal policy. Such a policy was implemented by the last Government, and it accomplished the object which that Government set out to achieve. I urge this Ministry to allow fiscal matters to stand until world conditions have become more stable. We could then overhaul our tariff, and see whether it is necessary to increase or reduce duties, so that Australian industries may be carried on efficiently, and so that there may be well-ordered development. We have had an appeal from Senator Duncan-Hughes that we should look to the wide horizon. The members of the party to which I belong claim that they are associated with the only party that, considers the tariff problem from a purely Australian point of view, unfettered by the clamorous demands of any particular section for recognition. We realize that the best interests of the workers, the primary producers, and the manufacturers would be served by a wellordered fiscal policy, which would protect efficient Australian industries, the majority of which are increasing in efficiency, and are well worthy of protection. That would help Australia to become the great country that it is destined to be.

talk.start.para: . - My contribution to this debate will be brief. We have been called together to discuss the tariff measure of this Government. We are now in the fourth week of that discussion, and we are still considering the second reading of the bill. The tariff has been debated from every possible angle, and I fail to see that it can be further talked about without a repetition of arguments that have already 'been advanced. It seems to me that the issue was settled last week, when a vote was taken on the amendment proposed by Senator Johnston. There the die was cas.t, and we saw the source from which the Government was receiving support for its tariff policy - from both, sections of the Labour party, and from that honorable senator who has proclaimed from Perth to Sydney that nobody in the Federal Parliament is nearer than he is to being a freetrader, but, having changed his outlook, will stand with the two sections of the Labour party in support of the measure brought down by this Government. The Government has the numbers, and it must shoulder the responsibility for this measure, with all its shortcomings, before the voters of Australia.

speech.para: In view of these circumstances, I wonder why we should continue to waste the time of the Senate, and the resources of the country, in prolonging a debate on an issue that, to all intents and purposes, has been settled by the vote taken here last week. Why waste time in debating the tariff in detail, as, I am afraid,, it will be during the next few weeks? Such a proceeding will be futile If we quickly conclude this debate, we shall remove from the minds of business men the doubt which must be occasioned by its continuance, and we shall give those men an opportunity to understand! the conditions under which they are supposed to try to develop their businesses, and the resources of this country. Then they will be able to concentrate on their own affairs. I shall not say more than that; but I should like honorable senators to consider whether it will not be wasting time to repeat arguments that have already been presented. It should be remembered that the industries of Australia can be graded in order of their prosperity, importance, and permanence, and it will be found that those qualities are in inverse ratio to the amount of government support and attention that they have had. I again appeal to honorable senators, and suggest to them that, as practically the issue has already been settled, we should finish the tariff as quickly as possible, and let the Government take the responsibility for the measure.

talk.start.para: .- Every honorable senator is not gifted to the same degree as Senator Elliott, with ability to condense his remarks effectively ; but I hope that I shall not occupy sufficient time to weary any honorable senator in my contribution to the debate on this most important measure. One has to recognize that, in view of present world conditions, no more important matter than our fiscal policy can be discussed, because on the fiscal policy of the world depends its fate. Much as we in Australia have prided ourselves in the past on being a self-contained country, we are now compelled to realize that we are, and always will be, dependent on the goodwill of other nations. Anything done to maintain the fetish set up by certain sections in Australia will only react to the disadvantage of the Commonwealth. I refer to the fetish which my honorable friends opposite call " protection ", but which i.s more accurately described as "prohibition of trade with any other country ". Under that policy Australia is prepared to sell to other countries, but not to buy from them. Wherever possible, it insists on other nations taking our produce and paying the highest possible price for it. I am pointing out, not the futility of the past action of honorable senators opposite, but the necessity for regarding this matter from a reasonable point of view.
- It is a pity the honorable senator does not reason on the same lines as those followed by Senator Elliott.

- I hope to be able to convert even the honorable senator who now interjects. Those who criticize the Government on this bill are charged with being freetraders; yet I have had no freetrade leanings throughout the whole of my political career. I have always regarded myself as a sound protectionist, but I am careful always to explain the difference between protection anil prohibition. To-day the Government is being assailed by honorable senators on the Opposition side on the ground that it has introduced a low tariff policy, and to justify them in this attitude, they assume that Australia, during the last three years, has had a tariff which has the approval of Parliament. The tariff that has been in operation during that period has never received the approval of this Parliament; it was never submitted to the Parliament by the Ministry which introduced it. That Government acted illegally, because it brought down resolutions providing for a much higher tariff than that now in operation without reference to the Tariff Board, and thus it was imposed contrary to the law of the land.

speech.para: Senator Crawford is a disciple of high protection; no tariff can be too high for him. On tariff matters he takes his place with those honorable senators who are associated with the Labour party. He referred to the Ottawa agreement in such terms as to bring it into contempt. He said that the British representatives drove a hard bargain at Ottawa, and he would have us assume that the people of Australia had been victimized to some extent by the agreement; but it is too early to criticize it, because the ink is hardly dry upon it. We have had no proper opportunity to test it; yet Senator Crawford is prepared to condemn it as being one sided. Personally, I believe that it is one sided, to a considerable extent, and that it favours Australia. Under the articles of the agreement, although provision is made for an increase of our British preferential rates, we find that many of the duties on British goods are high enough to be characterized as ' prohibitive.

Yet our primary products are being admitted to Great Britain at preferential rates of duty ranging from 1\ to 10 per cent. Will any honorable senator deny that that provision is in the best interests of Australia? Senator Crawford endeavoured to show that we were not reaping any practical advantages from this arrangement owing to the decline in the prices of our primary products. Surely no one will attribute the drop in commodities prices to anything that was done at Ottawa, or by the British representatives at that gathering. Consequently, statements of that character, made by Senator Crawford this afternoon, if intended as criticism of the work of the conference, are hardly worth considering. The honorable gentleman also went on to say that Australia had always been more or less a protectionist country, and supported his argument by mentioning the development that had taken place in protectionist Victoria prior to federation. I have taken the trouble to examine the Victorian tariff of 1893, and have compared the duties imposed by it with duties on similar items in the present schedule. On one item the Victorian ad valorem duty was 35 per cent., whereas the duty in the present Commonwealth schedule is 110 per cent. ; on another item the Victorian ad valorem duty was 45 per cent., and the present Commonwealth duty is 175 per cent. If, on this basis, the Victorian tariff was regarded as highly protectionist in character, what can be said of the present Commonwealth tariff schedule ?

When I spoke on the first reading of the bill I made special reference to the prevailing high duties in the Australian tariff, and endeavoured to show that they could not be defended on the ground that they were necessary for the maintenance of the manufacturing industries concerned. The views which I then expressed are fully supported in the supplementary report of the Tariff Board, issued on the 8th December last, dealing with piece goods, woollen or containing wool. Reference to two or three specific items will be sufficient to show how foolish is the policy which successive Commonwealth Governments have been following. . I cite first the duties on worsted materials for men's wear. The

Tariff Board's report shows that while the f.o.b. cost of such material in GreatBritain in 1932 was 6s. 9d. a yard, the landed duty-paid cost, under the Scullin tariff of 2s. per square yard, and 35 per cent, ad valorem, but excluding primage and exchange, was 13s. 4d. a yard. As the Australian manufacturers' selling price for comparable material was 6s. 6d. a yard, the landed cost of the British material, under the Scullin tariff, which honorable senators opposite are defending, was twice the price at which the local article could be sold to yield a reasonable profit in Australia. Another item was woollen material used for ladies' dresses. The landed cost under the Scullin tariff was 9s. Id. a yard, whereas similar material was manufactured in Australia and sold at 5s. 5d. a yard. In the face of these figures, can any one say that the Scullin tariff was reasonable protection?

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator would not object to that margin of profit if it went to British or Japanese manufacturers.

- I am not objecting to the Australian: manufacturers making a reasonable profit. I am merely endeavouring to show the folly of continuing to worship . this, fetish of so-called protection which, in the cases I have cited, makes the landed cost of British goods so high as to be prohibitive. Such tariff-making is midsummer madness.
- We should shut out altogether articles which we can make here.
- I like honorable senators to come out into the open. Senator Collings has just informed us that he would shut out imports altogether.
- Yes, importations of everything which we can manufacture in Australia.

- What would be the attitude of honorable senators opposite if other countries, upon which we depend for the sale of our surplus primary products, adopted the same fiscal policy and decided to close their doors against importations from Australia ?
- If the prices charged for our products are right, other countries will take them.

- I am afraid that my honorable friends opposite will have to change their views on tariff matters if we are going to get anywhere worth while. I listened attentively to Senator O'Halloran, who dwelt upon the increased consumption in Australia of locally-grown products during the last 23 years, his purpose being to show that the home market was the most profitable one for our primary producers. The honorable member overlooked, or ignored, the increase of population that had taken place during that period, which accounted for the larger absorption of local production, and also forgot to mention that he and his party have, for many years, set their faces definitely against the admission of migrants. How he can reconcile his advocacy of the development of the home market with opposition to immigration proposals, is beyond my understanding; because, obviously, it would be impossible, without a very large addition to our present population, to absorb any considerable increase of local production. Apparently honorable senators opposite forget the stock from which we have sprung, and overlook the fact that we owe so much to the courage and enterprise of the pioneers who came from the Mother Country to Australia.

speech.para: Senator Crawford, who spoke forcibly, and at some length, to-day, suggested in an interjection when Senator Carroll was speaking, that he had never been enthusiastic about the appointment of the Tariff Board, and, so far as he could remember, had not taken part in the debate on the proposal to set up such a board. The honorable gentleman was correct if, by that, he meant that he had not contributed to the second-reading debate; but he did speak on an amendment moved by Senator Wilson to limit the functions of the board. To-day the honorable gentleman suggested that the Government was allowing Australian tariff policy to be dictated by a board, which, he added, was really superseding Parliament, his general attitude on this question conveying the impression that he did not believe in the Tariff Board having any power whatever. As a matter of fact, the board's function is limited to inquiry and report upon matters referred to it. The act provides that before any alteration is made in the tariff, either by way of increasing or decreasing the duties, or by the insertion of a new item, the proposal must be referred to the board, which, after inquiry, submits its report to the Minister, who may thereupon take the necessary action. As the heavy additional duties levied by the Scullin Government three years ago were imposed without reference to the Tariff Board, they were imposed illegally. On the 27th July, 1921, Senator Crawford spoke to an amendment moved by Senator Wilson, the effect of which was to restrict inquiries by the board to items submitted to it by the Minister, instead of being allowed to make inquiries on its own initiative. I take the following from what the honorable senator said on that occasion: -

quote.para: I regard this clause as vital to the bill. In considering the amendment. I ask honorable senators to pay due regard to the obligation which is imposed upon the board by a subsequent clause, to report comprehensively to the Minister each year concerning the operation of the tariff and the development of industries. I cannot see how it is possible for the board to do that unless its members are free to make such inquiries as they may deem to be necessary.

If the clause lie amended in the manner that is proposed, or if it be omitted, we shall divest the board of every particle of independence, and practically reduce it to" the level of a political body, which possibly will deal only with such matters as the Minister may consider desirable for party or other purposes to refer to it. . . . If we amend the clause as now proposed, we shall make it impossible for the board to render useful service to the community.

speech.para: Could there have been a more ardent advocate of the principle underlying the Tariff Board Act than Senator Crawford? Yet the honorable senator suggested this afternoon that, because the Tariff Board is carrying out its functions as set out in the act, it is exercising a power greater than that possessed by this Parliament. On the occasion to which I have referred, Senator Crawford objected to any curtailment of the powers of the Tariff Board. He then contended that the board would be a most useful body - just the very thing the country required - but since it has been in existence, the honorable senator has expressed entirely opposite views.

When I spoke to the first reading of this bill, I was not feeling well, and since then I have had eight or ten days' illness. In my earlier speech, 1 made a statement which I have since found was not in accordance with fact. I shall not rectify my error now, but shall do so when the item concerned is under discussion in committee.

I hope that the proposal contained in this bill will be accepted by the Senate, for 1 believe that the Government has been actuated by the best intentions. It has had to deal with a situation which has never before arisen in Australia - a tariff schedule imposed on the people contrary to law. Under that illegal act - I use the term advisedly - many new industries sprang up, and others were extended, with the result that there was an over-production of manufactured goods, and the surplus could not be exported. On taking over the reins of office, the Government could not immediately have taken action to make the then existing duties ineffective. We must make the best of the situation which confronts us; we must pay the penalty for the illegal action of a previous government, but as speedily as possible repair the damage done. Let us do it in a commonsense way; let us give a reasonable measure of protection to those industries which need it, and remove from the schedule anything which will tend to create a monopoly. I admit that, at present, many of the things manufactured in Australia are being sold at reasonable prices, and their manufacture here may, in some instances, have reduced, rather than added to the cost of living; but I visualize the possibility in more prosperous times of these monopolies becoming a menace to the community. For that reason, and because I feel that it is essential that we should enter into the spirit of the world to-day, we should revise the schedule in such a way that we shall be able to face the world and say that all that we insist on is a reasonably protective tariff in order to conserve and encourage industries which are vital to the existence of the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: . - I wish ,to offer a few remarks in rebuttal of some of the statements of Senator Payne. The honorable senator said that we on this side of the chamber would have to alter our fiscal outlook if we were to get anywhere worth while. I assure the honorable senator that if the position of the world to-day, which is due to the policy believed in by Senator Payne, is " anywhere worth while ", we have no desire to alter our fiscal outlook. The last thing that we want to do is to repeat the disastrous performances which have brought the world to its present condition. The honorable senator went on to say that we on this side had set our faces against immigration. I assume that neither the honorable senator himself, nor the party to which he belongs, has done so. Any one who would suggest bringing one solitary immigrant into this country when 300,000 good Australians are compulsorily idle is an anti-Australian of the worst possible kind.

- I rise to a point of order. The honorable senator has misrepresented me - perhaps innocently. I did not suggest that Australia should embark on a policy of immigration at the present time; I said that the honorable senator and his party had set their faces against immigration when immigration was necessary in Australia some years ago.

- The honorable senator did not use the words "when immigration was necessary". He said that the party opposite - meaning the party to which I belong - had set their faces against immigration. Another remark made by the honorable senator was that we must repair the damage done by the illegal action of a previous Government. Similar damage to that which is apparent in Australia has been caused in every country in the world. It is for that reason that at this moment an economic conference of world leaders is sitting in London to face problems of great magnitude. The honorable senator would attempt to delude this chamber into the belief that only the "illegal fiscal action of a previous Australian Government " had placed this country in its present unsatisfactory position. . In common with other honorable senators opposite, Senator Payne disclaimed the statement that the Tariff Board is the supreme authority in fiscal matters in this country. No one who is capable of understanding the meaning of English can make me believe anything to the contrary, or that he himself believes it.
- Does the honorable senator think that the Tariff Board is superior to Parliament?
- It is a superparliament placed over this Parliament.
- Nonsense!
- Article 12 of the Ottawa agreement reads -

quote.para: His Majesty's Government in the Commonwealth of Australia undertake that no new protective duty shall be imposed, and no existing duty shall be increased, on United Kingdom goods to an amount in excess of the recommendation of the tariff tribunal.

speech.para: Yet honorable senators ask us 'to believe that, on that point at least, the Tariff Board is not to be supreme over Parliament.

On behalf of the party to which I belong, I protest most vigorously against the Tariff Board being made a superparliament. I object to any body being set up by this Parliament, and given authority to do things which Parliament itself ought to do. The Australian national parliament, meeting in Australia's national capital, and acting on behalf of the electors of Australia, should be the supreme authority in this country; but honorable senators know that it is not the supreme body, and that many of its members are merely puppets who dance to the tune called by the super-parliament set up by this legislature. We have the High Court, the Privy Council, royal commissions, Premiers conferences, the Loan Council, Sir Robert Gibson, the Tariff Board, economists, professors and experts, all of whom offer advice which is accepted in preference to the common-sense and intelligence of the men who comprise the national parliament of Australia. A World Economic Conference is now sitting in London, yet the members of this Parliament do not know what instructions have been issued to Australia's delegates to that conference. Notwithstanding the weighty problems which will be dealt with at London, the Parliament of Australia as awhole is ignorant of the attitude of the Australian Government towards them. We have, however, a shrewd suspicion of the Government's views.

A tariff schedule is a matter of national policy affecting, not only the rates of duty on imported goods, hut also the even bigger question of a White Australia. The present Government's fiscal policy, as contained in this bill, strikes a blow at Australia's national policy of a White Australia. So far as the welfare of the Commonwealth is concerned, there is no essential difference between admitting coloured labour into Australia, and allowing the products of low-wage coloured labour to come in and compete with the products of white labour in Australia. Half a century ago, when I was employed behind a grocery counter, practically everything used in the community was imported, either from England or from some foreign country. The Senate has to decide where it stands in regard to the policy of protection. The Labour party has taken a definite stand on this matter. Some surprise was expressed by honorable senators because, in a recent division, Labour senators supported the Government, and opposed the Country party. The reason was that they had to make their choice between Labour's ideal of a high tariff, the Government's ideal of a low tariff, and the Country party's ideal of no tariff at all.

We on this side do not underestimate the serious complexity of this problem. I think that it was Mr. Justice Higgins who, in referring to the tangle of industrial awards in Australia, said that they had got into a " Serbonian bog" of difficulty. That is exactly the kind of mess that we are getting into in connexion with tariff matters. The only comforting thought is that the difficulty is manmade, and it should be possible for the genius of our people to find a way out of the morass.

Honorable senators opposite . have quoted quite a galaxy of professors in support of their contention, and, incidentally, one honorable senator challenged members of the Labour party to cite an economist of standing who will champion the arguments which weadvance. I accept the challenge, and quote J. A. Hobson, who says -

quote.para: The world is in effect a single economic system and the improved or impaired productivity and consumption of every part affects every other part. Closer and more effective international movements for such improvements in the distribution of income as will enable world consumption to keep pace with and stimulate improvements in production, form the foundation of the progressive economy and the humaner civilization of the future.

speech.para: I do not expect honorable senators opposite to be able to grasp the splendid idealism that is contained in those words. We on this side are being continually accused of being merely destructive critics. However, as we indulge in our destructive criticism, we rarely fail to substitute a constructive policy for the faulty one which meets with our disfavour. Quite naturally, we have to support a destructive policy, because we believe that the world has ; been brought to such a state of misery and despair that matters can be set right only by first destroying the existing order of things, and then constructing our ideal in its place. One writer uses these words, which epitomises the position admirably: "We produce so much of everything that we have not enough of anything."

It is not often that I find myself prompted to compliment Senator Pearce on his utterances, but I must express my admiration of his brief speech, which gave us a splendid insight as to the complexity of the problems of exchange. The complexities of the fiscal position are not one whit less. During the last few days I have made a number of extracts from the press, and, while I shall not have sufficient time to read all of them, I shall select some which should assist to support my contentions. One extract reads -

quote.para: Mr. W. C. S. Thomas, the chairman of the Dried Fruits Board, when interviewed by the Australian Press Association, said that he had already found that conditions for the selling of dried fruits were worse than on previous seasons. This was duo to the heavy stocks of foreign imports. The foreign fruits poured into Britain in 1932 in anticipation of the Ottawa Treaty. This year's total of foreign arrivals was double that of 1931. " The Australian crop is particularly large - almost a record," he said. "The board is now planning a vigorous and continuous selling campaign, in the hope of attracting buyers to view the good Australian values offering."
However, no improvement in the commodity prices could be expected as long as the present over-production continued. He strongly depreciated the planting of further areas for dried fruits.

speech.para: Another extract reads -

debateinfo.title: NEW. ZEALAND RAISES TARIFF AGAINST AUSTRALIAN IMPORTS

debate.para: The latest interpretation of the benevolent Ottawa agreement is from New Zealand. Under this it is announced that the sister dominion is about to raise its tariff wall against a considerable number of Australian products. The new increased duties on imports from Australia cover the following: On and from 1st June, cut and plug manufactured tobacco; on and from 1st August, confectionery, fresh apricots, cherries, grapes, peaches, plums, tomatoes, cigarettes, spirits, floor coverings, apparel, and hosiery, fur skins and made-up furs, glass bottles, and jars, china ware, fancy goods, sporting requisites, toilet preparations, motor vehicles, sashes, and doors.

In making the announcement Prime Minister Coates said it was not the settled policy of New Zealand that duties on Australian products should be below those from the United Kingdom, except in the case of special good; such as timber and fish.

A telegram from Calcutta, which was received in Australia a week ago,states that India has imposed a dumping duty against certain textiles which are produced by Japan. I notice that, two days later, the following report was published : -

quote.para: The Indian duty increases during the week are evoking excited meetings of the Japanese Trade Association. Resolutions have been passed, demanding reprisals, including a boycott of Indian cotton.

debate.para: Those happenings go to indicate how complex is the problem.

talk.start.para: - The honorable senator will remember that I told him as much during the last session, and he resented my information.

- I do not remember having ever resented anything that was said by the honorable senator, because he never says anything that is worth while. Further elaborating my argument, I shall quote from a volume which I have obtained in the Parliamentary Library, entitled, Soviet Trade and World Depression, and written by a man with a world-wide reputation, Mr. H.R. Knickerbocker. It is a remarkable book, and I recommend honorable senators to obtain this copy from the

speech.para: Library and peruse it. It opens up with the following remarks : - -

quote.para: Largest department store -on earth, the ' Soviet Union Foreign Trade Monopoly, is conducting the greatest permanent bargain sale in history, and in 52 lands its agents to-day are offering a thousand varieties of wares at prices that bring despair to their competitors.

What these offers mean first of all to America, one of the Soviet Union's chief competitors for the European market, is a principal object of this investigation of Soviet trade in Europe's chief industrial cities, ports and capitals, an investigation undertaken on the eve of the spring and summer export campaign of the Soviet Union that is expected to bring increased quantities of Soviet goods on a market already groaning from over-supply.

speech.para: I hope that I shall have the opportunity to talk of doing something of that nature in Australia a little later on. When this book was written in 1931, the trade of Soviet Russia was expanding in an astonishing fashion. This is the description of an exhibit at Milan -

quote.para: Here at hand in the flesh, in the can, in the bale, and in the bolt, is a visible part of the inventory of the biggest sales organization in the world, ready to furnish anything from worm medicine for overfed lapdogs to marble gravestones and linen doilies, ready to meet and cut anybody's price from cotton to coal! lt is an astonishing exhibition, and Soviet macaroni in Italy is only one of its revelations. There in a corner is a stand taller than a man, brilliantly lit with thin-necked globular electric light bulbs. They are for sale. They are Soviet products. Three years ago the best the Soviet Union could do in the way of producing instruments, of illumination was to turn out with the help of Swedish concessionaires poor-quality kerosene lanterns. Today they are exporting electric light bulbs indistinguishable to the layman from the most modern products of American or German factories. Patents, it may be remarked, are one of the least of Soviet worries. . . .

Here are wheat, 39 varieties, and flour, four kinds, for white bread - last seen in Russia in 1928. Here arc six sorts of cornmeal, eleven of benns, and four grades of sugar. Last autumn in the considerable city of Dnepropetrovsk we could find no sugar. Distribution difficulties were to blame, we were told, and it is true that sugar was available everywhere else en route through the Soviet Union. But distribution runs smoother when the outlet is abroad and foreign currency the goal.

Here are 20 sorts of peas and seed vegetables, barley, oats, rye, and, finally, the macaroni. Not just macaroni though, but all calibres in between, from finger-thick noodles to hair-fine vermicelli. In this department is material for every sort of nutriment, from French pastry, to mast for swine.
Every department has its director, anxious to distribute literature, ready to explain that the objects on exhibition arc only a fraction of those the Soviet Union could supply. . . .

One whole section is devoted to petroleum and every conceivable variety of petroleum product, and another to lumber and wood products, now the largest Soviet export. Here are parquet floorings, plywood, ready-made doors, sashes, sawn timber, planks.

Upstairs are rugs, antique and new; 41 kinds of bristles; 18 of feathers; 12 sorts of sausage casings; 24 samples of hemp goods, including ropes, mats and nets; 25 kinds of horse-hair; 05 of furs; 150 examples of fine porcelain; two shelves full of common crockery; a whole department for peasant handwork - toys, dolls, embroidered linen, balalaikas and mandolins.

Downstairs, on the other side, we came up short before three bales of Russian cotton. In 1928, the first year of the five-year plan, the Soviet Union imported nearly 500,000 bales of cotton, 300,000 of them from the United States of America.
A short distance from the baled cotton stand cases of textile samples. More than 300 varieties of Soviet cotton and linen goods are offered for sale.

We hurry along past 30 kinds of hides :ind leather; waterproofing oil; wax; vermifuge for dogs; 93 kinds of chemicals, prepared and raw; 15 sorts of granite and marble; a case of semi-precious stones; and 45 kinds of other minerals; and pause once more before a corner full of silk - raw silk and silk cocoons. There is much to learn in the Soviet trade exhibit. Lost year Italy bought more than £200.000 worth of cocoons and about £40,000 worth of raw silk from the Soviet Union, where a pair of silk stockings is rarer than white bread.

speech.para: I could continue to quote from this book for quite a time, for there is a great deal more that is of interest in it. The point that I wish to make on this matter of vital policy is that the nations which are assembled at the World Economic Conference in London will not do anything that will be of value to Australia. With Australia, those nations are faced with the tremendous flood of exports which will come, not only from Russia, but also from every other highly industrialized country .that is engaging in a policy of intense economic development and nationalism, and is becoming less and less dependent on other countries. Yet we sit in this chamber and try to deceive ourselves and those whom we represent that, along orthodox lines, we shall find a way out of the difficulty.
If evidence were required as to the futility of our methods and the fallacy of pinning our faith to the World

Economic Conference, it is to be found in the description of the opening of the proceedings of that conference which appears in to-day's Sydney Morning Herald. At that gathering 66 nations arc represented, and 267 delegates are sitting; but within a few hours of its opening no notice was taken of any but the most prominent personages. The newspapers comment that no concentration of thought is possible at the conference, as nobody seems to be able to do any individual thinking, because smoking is not permitted in the conference room. Despite the dreadful tragedy of present day conditions, and the destruction of so much that is dear to most of us, we have presented to our notice a picture which would be farcical if it were not so tragic, of the elect of the peoples of the world sitting in solemn conclave at that Economic Conference unable to concentrate their thoughts because they are not allowed to smoke, while millions remain unemployed and, even in this wonderful continent of ours, hundreds of thousands go hungry.

talk.start.para: - "Will the honorable senator now support Empire economic unity to the full?

- I wish to show that they live in a fool's paradise who try to persuade themselves that Senator Elliott's panacea for all the ills to which flesh is heir - economic and otherwise - may be solved by some indefinable specific that he is pleased to designate " Empire unity." And to indicate how much that is likely to be worth in the days that are to come, I have obtained from the Parliamentary Library a work that was written quite recently entitled America Conquers Britain. Apparently, the world regards with admiration the Prime Minister of Great Britain, Mr. Ramsay MacDonald, because he went across to the United States of America, and held goodwill parleys with President Hoover-
- Does not the honorable senator refer to President Roosevelt ?
- I was alluding to Hoover; I was not referring to the recent parleys. According to this work,

speech.para: Lieutenant-Commander J. M. Kenworthy, M.P., says - " The danger of Anglo-American conflict is as real as was the danger of war between Britain and Germany in 1905. We are heading straight for the same tragedy as 1914." Field-Marshal Sir William Robertson, former Chief of the British General Staff, frankly compares the United States to the Prussia of 1914.

I should like honorable senators to pay particular attention to this, because it furnishes reasons for the refusal of those who sit on this side of the chamber to accept the time-worn platitudes of' our friends opposite. It goes on to say -

quote.para: In the midst of the Hoover-MacDonald friendship negotiations the MacDonald Government officially and directly was fighting two special trade battles against the United States, and the Hoover Administration officially was trying to force through Congress a higher tariff law deliberately designed to exclude many British products from this country. The MacDonald Government sent the official d'Abernon mission to the Argentine Government and obtained an agreement giving Britain many millions of dollars' worth of trade which had been going to the United States, and which Mr. Hoover hoped to retain on the strength of his Argentine tour a few months earlier. While Mr. MacDonald was nearing New York on his visit to the President, his Cabinet colleague, Mr. J. H. Thomas, was boasting of having taken a large amount of Canadian coal and steel trade away from the United States.

Mr. Thomas in making to the Brighton Conference of the Labour party the first official announcement of the result of his Canadian mission, said, " I found that Canada was importing from the United States 15,000,000 tons of bituminous coal every.year. I convinced the Canadians that some of that should come from England and Wales, because every 300 tons mined in this country means enough work to support a miner and his family one year." - and he, might have added, means work taken away from American miners of whom tens of thousands are unemployed, and other tens of thousands arc on part time.

talk.start.para: - Does not that refer to the previous MacDonald Ministry ?
- It refers to the present Ministry. It also says -

quote.para: This does not mean that the Prime Minister and the President in their goodwill negotiations and statements were hypocrites. But it does mean that the trade war at the same time is increasing with a force which sweeps Prime Ministers and Presidents along with it.

speech.para: That is the point 'that I wish to make. We mouth time-honoured platitudes as though nothing new had happened in the world, when within the last decade, in fact, within the last three years, there have been such wonderful occurrences that all pre-conceived notions are to-day inexpressible futilities.

What is the problem that we have to solve, and which every other country so far has found unsolvable? We have a wonderful opportunity to solve it, but we cannot do so by putting into practice what every other country has already tried. Every avenue, everyby-way, every high-way along that track has been explored time and again, until today all the world's great authorities admit that a solution is not to be found in such directions. What is the problem? I have taken some extracts from the public press, and in no case shall I quote from a Labour organ. The following is from Western Australia, that State which sends to this chamber so many of our ablest senators: -

subdebate.1.para: At a meeting at Bunbury, the Rev. R. J. C. Butler severely criticized the treatment of unemployed single men. " The plight of the single men is about the worst feature of the depression," he said. "That hundreds of young men should be forced to live on charity and be free from discipline and training for work during the most important years of their lives is nothing less than a tragedy."

This is the point that I wish to emphasize - " If war broke out to-morrow these same young men would be drafted into camps, fed, clothed, given wages, and trained for destruction, and no talk about shortage of money would hinder this being done. "To-day these young men are being treated literally as human scrap. Such a policy is going to result in our nation reaping a terrible harvest. Every citizen with a sense of justice should demand that something be done to enable these young men to be trained for the constructive work of peace."
Lord Melchett, writing in the London Sunday Chronicle, says -

quote.para: There are legions of young men, intelligent, honest, and patriotic, who are face to face with the fact - not the fear, but the fact - that under the present system they may never be employable in any circumstances whatever. Not even if they stand in queues for fifty years, and answer advertisements by every post!

subdebate.1.para: Yet we sit in this chamber, facing with equanimity the terrible holocaust that has been prepared for us, and do nothing except mouth the time-honoured platitudes that have salved the legislative conscience and kept the crowd over-awed during the last 100 years. What are the facts concerning the United States of America, that country which has fallen perhaps to a greater extent than others, on the principle that the higher one climbs, the further one falls?
