One of its latest returns, compiled in April of this year, says that there are 12,000,000 unemployed, 9,000,000 working part time, and 45,000,000 living in poverty. Thus in the richest country in the world some 40 per cent. of the population live in poverty, many millions of them in absolute destitution. Yet we are sneered at by honorable senators opposite because we voice some original ideas, stress our desire to get down to fundamentals, and definitely refuse, and will continue to refuse, to be bulldozed by the trash which the Government, and those who stand for it, attempt to put over us. Here is another view of the American situation -

quote.para: Tens of millions hardly know where their next meal is to come from. Industrial equipment worth tens of billions is rotting and rusting in idleness. Food to support millions is eaten by maggots, weevils, and . rodents, while children go hungry. Millions of bales of wool and cotton glut warehouses, while patched overalls are becoming the fashion for both men and women. Side tracks are crowded with idle engines and cars, while every highway is crowded with footsore hitch-hikers. The whole thing is an insult to intelligence, a challenge to civilization, an affront to ordinary horse-sense and common decency.

subdebate.1.para: I have a further authority which I am confident that my friends opposite will accept as worthy of some attention. This reads -

quote.para: In an address at West St.Kilda yesterday, Archbishop Mannix said he was not a Communist or a Socialist, but he could understand how people were driven to extremes in times like the present. Millions of people in all lands were starving, while the world was full of wealth. The first line of defence against Communism and Socialism was to acknowledge humbly and sorrowfully that the system under which they were living had been a complete failure.

subdebate.1.para: My desire in submitting this evidence is that, in our fiscal policy, we shall not be guilty of perpetuating further the programme that has brought disaster to the other countries of the world. We are told that we must practise economy. That term has been worked overtime. What is the meaning of the suggestion which has been the burden of the song of all honorable senators who have spoken during this debate, except those 'who belong to the party of which I am a member? They have all said that we must reduce production costs, that we must be able to compete with the other countries of the world with our export surplus. Carried to its logical conclusion, what does that mean? We have the finest and the richest country in the world, a country in which we ought to be able to, and can, produce much more than we can consume, even under favorable conditions; yet we are merely asked to allow Australia to enter into a poverty competition with the other peoples of the world, in which the prize can go only to the country that is willing to submit to the lowest conditions. Mr. J. M. Keynes is an authority that our friends opposite sometimes accept, and whom they have actually quoted in this chamber during this debate. They will not agree with the following quotation from ope of his works: -

quote.para: If we carry " Economy " of every kind to a logical conclusion, we shall find we have balanced the budget at nought on both sides, with all of us flat on our backs, starving to death from a refusal, for reasons of economy, to buy one another's services.

subdebate.1.para: I was interested in the very fine speech delivered by the Vice-President of the Executive Council (Senator McLachlan) in opening this debate. He said -

quote.para: Upon election to office the present Government introduced, in February, 1932, a tariff schedule which gave effect to its pre-election promise. Summarized, its tariff policy was -

item.para: Efficient industry as an essential qualification for tariff shelter.

subdebate.1.para: When are we to decide the stage at which an industry that is proposed to be started; or that is already started, becomes an efficient industry within the meaning of that paragraph? The honorable senator knows perfectly well- that an . industry must be given a trial. We have heard from honorable senators opposite about backyard industries, abortive industries, and all that kind of thing. MacRobertson's confectionery business, which to-day is the largest of its kind in the southern hemisphere, began in a backyard. At what stage should iV have become necessary ta decide whether that industry was efficient or not? The next paragraph reads -

item.para: A competitive, as distinct from a prohibitive, tariff level.

subdebate.1.para: When are we to decide the point at which a tariff becomes competitive, and when it ceases to be competitive and becomes prohibitive? One honorable senator has said that he has never yet met a 100 per cent, protectionist. Let me introduce him to at least one honorable senator who is a 100 per cent, protectionist. I hold the view, and my party also, that a tariff which brings in revenue is not a protective tariff, and that the more revenue it brings in, the less protective it is. When it can be demonstrated that we can produce in Australia a commodity equal in' quality to the imported article and sell it at practically the same price, it should be made a penal offence to bring the im-' ported article into this country. By importing articles which can be made effectively in Australia, we give employment to people overseas instead of to the people within our own shores. The third point in the present Government's tariff policy which, as- Senator McLachlan has stated, was promised at the last election, is -

quote.para: Tariff making through the Tariff Board, and not by arbitrary ministerial action.

subdebate.1.para: What will be the attitude of the people of Australia when their representatives in this Senate tell them that the Government has decided that tariff-making, which finally decides what standard of comfort is to be enjoyed by the community, what shall be on the breakfast table of the working-class families, and what standard of prosperity the primary producers shall enjoy, is to be taken out of the hands of this Parliament and placed unblushingly in the hands of the Tariff Board? Honorable senators are paid a salary for doing this kind of work, and that salary is increased when an honorable senator becomes a cabinet minister. Why should we who are paid to frame the tariff policy of the country be everlastingly transferring our responsibility to outside bodies which are in no way answerable to the electors for their actions, thus shirking our own responsibilities? Later in his address, Senator McLachlan said -

quote.para: The policy of this Government, as expressed at the last elections and endorsed by the people may be briefly summarized as being, " Protection for efficient and. economic industries on a competitive, as distinct from a prohibitive, level," and, " The Government will be guided largely by the recommendations of the Tariff Board, and will not, generally speaking, engage in tariff making by arbitrary ministerial action."

subdebate.1.para: First of all, the Minister stated that tariff making would be undertaken through the Tariff Board, and not by arbitrary ministerial action, but afterwards, he obviously became doubtful of the wisdom of announcing such a clear-cut tariff programme, and he watered it down by saying that the Government would be "guided largely by the recommendations of the Tariff Board." But the Ottawa agreement provides that no existing duties shall be increased on the United Kingdom goods to an amount in excess of the recommendation of the Tariff Board. The Government, therefore, must, in certain instances, accept the recommendation of the board. The Minister also stated - lt is most remarkable that we should bc considering a tariff schedule at the present stage, and particularly on the eve of the World Economic Conference, at which the tariff policy of each government will be submitted to the most searching scrutiny. It is to be hoped that, at this conference, the futility of adopting prohibitory tariffs and trade restrictions will be fully appreciated, and that future world policy will be in the direction of freeing the channels of trade from the obstructions designedly, but in good faith, placed upon them.

What does that statement mean? It means that we are to adopt a policy which will remove restrictions of trade brought about by the operation of the tariff. Such an action would be entirely opposed to the will of the people, and to the election promises of this Government. The Minister made use of this pregnant remark -

quote.para: It is of no use to blink the fact that the world is passing through the greatest crisis recorded in its history.

subdebate.1.para: Yet, when Labour senators were addressing this chamber on this important subject, the Senate was practically deserted, there being few members of the United Australia party and the- United Country party present.

talk.start.para: - And few Labour senators were present.
- -The honorable senator's power of mathematical calculation has evidently deteriorated since

speech.para: I first knew him, because, when, by interjection, I drew attention to the state of the Senate, I counted the members on this side of the chamber, and, out of a possible attendance of ten members, six were present. Obviously honorable senators supporting the Government are trying to blink the fact that the world is passing through the greatest crisis recorded in its history. The Minister continued: -

quote.para: In Australia we may flatter ourselves that we have surmounted our worst difficulties.

speech.para: Everybody knows that Australia is a long way from prosperity. We can easily persuade ourselves, comfortably placed as we are, that the worst is over, but it would be extremely difficult to persuade the people who are suffering, because of the un-Australian policy of this Government, that the worst is past. Even if prosperity should return to certain sections of the community, it would mean nothing to the people who are sheltering in shacks which let in the rain, and shivering because of the winter's cold, and whose women and children are ill provided for. We cannot tell those people that the corner has been turned, and that the worst is past. Prosperity will never return to Australia unless we adopt a prohibitive fiscal policy, and place round this continent a tariff wall which will make it self-contained, and enable the people at least to live under decent standards, and free altogether from the frightful and horrible competition of Japan, Great Britain, Denmark, the Argentine, Czechoslovakia, and other countries, which are pouring their products into this country. We cannot blink our eyes to the facts, and no amount of soft talk will persuade the people who are suffering that anything like prosperity has returned to Australia. Senator McLachlan continued -

quote.para: We should ask ourselves how the position is likely to affect, not only civilization, but also the future of. the British race.

speech.para: Our first consideration should be for our own people. The provision of employment for them is a big enough problem for us to tackle, and, when we have solved it and actually brought prosperity to Australia, then it will, be time enough for us to interest ourselves in the welfare of other members of the British race. Senator McLachlan went on to say -

quote.para: Are we to fall to the level of other nations, who to-day, by means of depreciated currencies, economic practices of which we do not approve, and the adoption of standards of living which we could never adopt, are gaining markets from us, and may eventually place us on the " outer " from the economic view-point.

speech.para: We cannot have a lower standard of living than we have in Australia for those who are unemployed and hungry, and the Minister's reference to the lowstandards of other countries seems to me to be the worst kind of political hypocrisy. If other countries are gaining markets from us, we must do something to help ourselves. The Minister stated -

quote.para: When nations see their way to make both ends meet in regard to their external obligations, and to release exchange control without the collapse of currency, most of these barriers will disappear.

speech.para: Australia has never failed to make both ends meet. When we borrowed millions of pounds from Great Britain that country possessed a yardstick by which our indebtedness to it at that time could be measured; but since then, and without reference to us, that yardstick has been considerably lengthened. Instead of being 12 inches to the foot, it is now 23 inches to the foot. That calculation has been worked out from statistics. As I have said previously in this chamber, we are to-day paying in respect of our liabilities to the bondholders, three hales of wool where previously one sufficed. Australia has been able to pay what it justly owes to other countries, and Great Britain has nothing to complain about in that respect as I shall show later. The honorable senator continued -

quote.para: The dilemma is the usual vicious circle. Exchange control cannot be withdrawn before the return of confidence andconfidence waits on the withdrawal of exchange control.

speech.para: That remark may be a pearl of wisdom, but after searching it inside and outside so far as my intelligence has permitted me, I cannot find anything in it except that we have become involved in a vicious circle, and that there is no escape from it except by leaping out of it and adopting a policy different from that which placed us in that vicious circle. The Minister continued -

quote.para: Like individuals, they must live within their own means - but in the urgent necessity for finding this new equilibrium, all nations have been forced to accept a lower standard.

speech.para: What is this "new equilibrium" at the back of the mind of the honorable senator ?

There is no specific remedy for the confusion into which the world has been thrown, yet the direction in which relief must be sought is clearly apparent. It is by a movement towards the liberation of private enterprise, industry, and commerce.

That is the first sign of any constructive capacity in the whole of the Minister's speech. Now we know exactly what the remedy is, and before I resume my seat, I shall submit a remedy in contradistinction to his. At last we have had a clear declaration from the Minister in charge of the bill to the effect that we can only attain salvationby a movement towards the liberation of private enterprise, industry and commerce. I should like to ask the Minister, in all reason, who or what policy is responsible for this vicious circle. It cannot be anything else but private enterprise. Government control has never operated in any country in the world except the one, some facts regarding which I quoted earlier in my remarks. Private enterprise, industry and commerce are exactly the things that have got us into the mess we are in. It is hypocrisy, and an insult to our intelligence, merely to throw across the chamber to us one constructive thought in the midst of columns of talk, and that merely a suggestion that to continue the same policy that has got us into our trouble will get us out of it. That sort of necromancy makes no appeal to me.'

talk.start.para: - The New Australia movement did not do very much, either.

- I shall have a word to say on that subject on another occasion. The honorable senator does not know anything about the New Australia movement. I do know something about it, because I was the Queensland agent for it. The men engaged in it were all personal friends of mine. I know the history of it, and the only regret I have, Mr. President, over your elevation to the proud position you now enjoy, is that it deprives me of the opportunity of convincing you, as well as Senator Herbert Hays, of the truth regarding the New Australia movement.

speech.para: The Minister in charge of the bill went on to say that "every debtor nation, in order to meet its obligations as far as possible, and to save its currency from collapse, had to limit its imports, knowing full well that those imports were its neighbour's exports." That was exactly what the Scullin Government did. That Government limited imports for two reasons. If it did not, the volume of our export surplus would not have been sufficient to correct our adverse trade balance on the other side of the world. But it 'also limited imports - which were our neighbour's exports - for another reason: Every time we make an article in Australia, we have the article and the money it costs to make it, inside the country ; but every time we buy an article from another country, we have the article, while the other country has the money and the employment. One honorable senator, in his hysteria, referred to the "illegal fiscal acts of the Scullin Government," which, he said, had got Australia into the mess it is in to-day. The Minister in charge of the bill said that, until the cost of production in secondary industries was scaled down to a point more in relation to the price of raw materials, there could be no real improvement. What does that mean ? It is always a good thing, when examining the speeches of somebody opposed to you, to try to visualize his point of view. There are two sides to every argument. That was said at a political meeting not long ago by a candidate who was anxious to ingratiate himself with the electors whose votes he was seeking. He recognized, he said, that there were two sides to every question, and his hearers were entitled to their own opinions. A wag at the back of the hall called out that there were two sides to every flypaper, but it made a great deal of difference to the fly which side he landed on. The Minister in charge of the bill said that there could be no real improvement until prices were scaled down. Well, how far down? There is only one meaning behind that statement. In his opinion we must get our production costs down to the lowest standard existing in any country that produces the same article. [Extension of time granted.]
We must get our costs down so as to compete with that country which has the lowest standard of living and of production costs.

Senator Crawford commenced his speech by saying that we all had high hopes of Ottawa. I desire to wash my hands of that statement. I expected nothing from Ottawa; I got nothing from Ottawa, and Australia has got- nothing from it. It does not matter how much honorable senators opposite may try to deceive themselves, and persuade the primary producers that they got something out of Ottawa; the producers themselves know that ,they got noth-ing out of it. The honorable senator also said that he had high., hopes of the World Economic Conference, now meeting in London. I make, this prophecy : Nothing will emerge from that conference except talk; because not one of the delegates dares to go. ''back to. his own country, and tell those who sent him that the only way out of the difficulty is to adopt the Labour party's policy. That policy provides that, instead of production, distribution and exchange pf wealth being carried on for private profit, we should reverse the process, and carry them on for the public benefit. None of the delegates is game to go back and make that statement, but salvation exists nowhere else. None of them, will go back and say that at last the people should have intelligence and moral courage enough to demand that the finance of their country should be taken away from the criminal control of private enterprise, of private dividend-mongering, ' profit-making banks and other financial institutions, and that the nation's credit should be used for the nation's needs, so that it may do good work for the whole of the community.

talk.start.para: - A nice old mess the Labour party made of things in Queensland.

- I do not expect Senator Sampson to understand what I am talking about, and my remarks have not been addressed to him. I never attempt the impossible. I am addressing those honorable senators opposite who have taken part in this debate, and have endeavoured to give the Senate some evidence of a glimmering of latent intelligence.

speech.para: Senator Crawford went on to say that our interest payments should be accounted to us as part of the value Australia is to Great Britain. As a matter of fact they are so accounted now. They are not paid in cash : they are paid in goods, and we get full credit for all the goods we sent to Great Britain. The honorable senator spread himself out and looked like Ajax defying the lightning, while he spoke as though he had discovered something original. We can expect no originality from those who are chained to the wheel of a system which has done so much damage in the world for the last century or more.

We have been told by other honorable senators that it is all a matter of export. In my opinion, the sooner we concentrate on exports for the purpose only of discharging existing liabilities, and not for the purpose of buying abroad goods which can 'be produced in Australia, the better it will be for all of us. How long do we intend, to produce tons and tons of goods, much of which we could consume ourselves if we were given an opportunity, but which now, in the final analysis, have the effect merely of reducing the standard of living of the primary producers? But how else are we to pay our overseas debts, honorable senators may ask? Let us decide, now that Australia's jamboree has lasted long enough, that we have been living in a fool's paradise long enough, borrowing money long enough, and too long piling up burdens for posterity. State and Commonwealth Governments went on gaily year after year borrowing money overseas. We said, with a magnanimous wave of the hand, "We must pass some of this on tu> preterity." Unfortunately, we are posterity; we are experiencing the bitter aftermath, the morning after the night before. If we are to be honest to posterity let us decide now that we shall put the peg in. Let there be no more borrowing abroad. Let Australia be a self-contained nation. Some of us may have to go short of some of the things which we have been educated to believe are necessities, but which, in reality, are not. We m'ay have to get back to a less complex form of existence, but let us get back to it. Then, in a little virile, this nation, proceeding along right Lines and giving the common people a cil mee,' will be able to produce, not only the necessities, but also those things which are called luxuries.

Honorable senators have spoken about our duty to the Empire. I do not know of any other part of the Empire which has discharged its duty in that respect better than Australia has done. I wonder how many honorable senators opposite know, or will admit, that Australia is Britain's second best customer. The Victorian Agent-General, Mr. W. Leitch, now Sir W. Leitch, discussing this matter, is reported "as follows: -

quote.para: Dealing with some British people who complained that Australia would not buy British goods, and pointed to the tariff to support their contention, Mr. Leitch rather crushingly pointed out that Australia, with 6,000,000 people, bought £54,000,000 worth of British goods a year, and was Britain's second best customer, first on the list being India, which country, with 320,000,000 people, bought £78,000,000 worth. Further than that, over six years' trading, to 1930, Australia was the only country in the world to give Britain a credit balance. What an effective reply to the croakers in this, country!

talk.start.para: - We have been saying that for years.

- If . the honorable senator has known it for years, why does he support a fiscal policy which will have the effect of continuing us in bondage to a country of which we have been, in the past, such an excellent customer ?

speech.para: I was interested, on entering the chamber the other evening, to hear Senator Kingsmill expatiating on brotherhood. L do not know whether it was my patriarchal and benevolent appearance that prompted Senator Kingsmill to refer to me as " the elder brother ", but I accepted the remark as a sincere compliment. If there is one thing that I believe in more than another, it is brotherhood. I waited to hear the words that Senator Kingsmill had to say on the subject of brotherhood, but I waited in vain, for he did not utter them. I ask honorable senators opposite whether brotherhood is possible to-day? It becomes less and less possible. The Golden Rule is an impossibility, because brotherhood has been made impossible. To-day, in consequence of economic insecurity and the problem of not knowing where to-morrow's dinner is coming from, nation is competing against nation, State against State, town against town, and individual against individual. The tens of thousands of young men and women of whom Lord Melchett said, that "if they stand in queues for 50 years and answered advertisements by every post " they would not find work, for they would be unemployable, know all too well that brotherhood is a dream that cannot be realized. If honorable senators would exercise some constructive statesmanship we might be able to improve things a little. Senator Duncan-Hughes, in railing against high tariffs, asked why we should impose a duty of 45 per cent. against boots made in Great Britain, thus preventing the down-at-heel people in this country from buying them. Does not the honorable gentleman realize that these people cannot buy Australian boots made of Australian material by Australian workmen in Australian factories? How then could they buy British boots? The honorable senator must know that they could not do anything of the kind. The same honorable gentleman said that we should never lose sight of the importance of the primary producers who are mainly responsible for our export business. Honorable senators of the Labour party do not lose sight of the primary producers. We are interested in them, not only because of the exportable goods which they produce, but also for other reasons which I have already mentioned. We say that this country should stop borrowing abroad, for that policy only increases the load of debt which we have to carry, and which we are expected to pay off, not by the yardstick of 12 inches, which was in use when the money was borrowed, but by the yardstick which, without any authority from this country, has been increased to 23 inches.

Senator Duncan-Hughes who is always courteous, if not always logical, asked by interjection while Senator Brown was speaking, what we would do with our. wool and meat. There has been an ad misericordiam appeal for weeks by honorable senators opposite on behalf of the wool and meat producers of this country. The Government has been besieged with requests to do something for the wool producers, and to stimulate the meat industry. But what is the good of talking about increasing our exportable surplus when our producers arefinding it increasingly difficult to produce at a profit? I believe it is true that some of them are to-day producing at a loss. The fact is that the nations of the world are becoming less and less dependent uponus for wheat and meat. Wool is the only thing that Australia is now producing that the nations of the world must buy from us, and it will not be long before they will be able to do without our wool. They are doing without our wheat, butter, cheese, and meat to an ever-increasing extent. Senator Badman also interjected while Senator Brown was speaking, and I believe that he was sincere when he said that the men engaged in secondary industries were not pioneers, but were protected, and that the men engaged in primary production were pioneers, but were not protected. I cannot imagine Senator Badman being insincere in anything, but that remark almost tempts me to test the strength of the honorable gentleman's sincerity.

talk.start.para: -"Yield not to temptation."

- If I could yield to this temptation I should be happy, but there are sound and sufficient reasons why I should not do so. If Senator Badman had exercised common sense hewould not have made such an interjection. He and his colleagues seem to confine their attention to effects. Honorable senators of the Labour party devote their attention to causes. I should like to test the sincerity of some honorable senators opposite. I should like to see what Senator Payne would do if a proposition were made to withdraw protection from the hop-growers of Tasmania on the ground that they are not pioneers. Of course they are pioneers. I should also like to see what senators from Victoria would do if an attempt were made to withdraw protection from the potato and oniongrowers, and the butter producers, of that State. If the duty of 6d. per lb. on New Zealand butter, and the assistance given to the dairy-farmers by the Paterson scheme, were withdrawn there would be trouble. Senator Brennan, who usually prefaces anything of a particularly caustic nature that he has . to say to honorable senators on this side of the chamber, with the words " with all respect to my friends ", would be very annoyed if any move of the kind that I have suggested were made.
- What about peanuts ?

- This Government has already laid its devastating hand upon the Queensland peanut, pineapple, banana, tobacco, and rum industries, and I and my colleagues on this side of the chamber who represent Queensland will have something to say on those subjects when the specific items are under notice. I should also like to offer a. word of advice to my innocent young friend, Senator Foll, who, I regret is not in the chamber at the moment. I do so with all kinds of Brennan-like respect. The unsophisticated speeches which Senator Foll delivers might lead people to think that he is anything but the knowing gentleman that he is. He told us that the primary producers have "got it in the neck ". He used much more elegant language, but that is what he meant. He suggested also that the arbitration awards which apply to the working class should be policed. I assure' the honorable senator that when the Labour party comes into power again in about eighteen months' time-
- Is the honorable senator a prophet?

- I am prepared to stake my political reputation on the prophecy I have just made. Several honorable senators opposite who are adepts at interjecting will not be in this chamber very much longer to use such bait. The political axe will fall upon them. My advice to Senator Foll is that he should advocate the policing of primary production. In the platform of the Labour party there is a plank which reads " New protection ". When we get an opportunity, it will be our duty to put that plank into operation. We shall not allow manufacturers to exploit the consumers, behind the shelter of the tariff wall. In reply to the charge which has been levelled against us with sickening iteration, that under the tariff there is danger of exploitation of the consumers, all I have to say is that if we are tq be robbed at all, it is better to be robbed by

speech.para: Australian manufacturers, who will spend the proceeds of their robbery in the Commonwealth, than by overseas manufacturers who never come near us.

talk.start.para: - Why be robbed at all?

- When ye have an honest government, it will see that the people are not robbed. Oliver Wendel Holmes once said that there are only two classes in the community - those who go ahead and do things, and those who merely stand off and criticize. I think that he was about right. But another author, less eminent in the literary world, has said that the only two classes in the community are those who do the work, and those who " do " the workers. That is true in Australia to-day. On the fiscal issue, gibes are thrown at us by honorable 'senators opposite. It is incorrectly stated - and all their gibes are inaccurate - that by the " worker " we mean only the man who wears bowyangs, and has corns on his hands. Let us hear no more of that unfair charge, because the Labour movement's definition of a worker is, " Every member of the community who is rendering useful service to the community, no matter what the nature of that service may be ".
- He has also to be a member of a union.

- No ; he merely needs to be a citizen who is rendering some useful service. The definition includes the farmer. No member of the community works harder than the primary producer, and none is robbed more of his wealth. He has never had a chance in any country, let alone in Australia.

speech.para: Many authorities have been quoted by honorable senators opposite in an attempt to substantiate their arguments. The following is a statement by J. K. Bellerby. professor of economics at. the University of Liverpool : -

debate.para: It would be no use giving the money to those who are playing the safety v game. If the Government, receiving the credit from the bank, handed it over to those whose desire is to save every penny they receive, then the result would be nil. We must avoid this plague of safety seeking. As a sheer necessity for trade revival, we must give the money to those who are so needy that they will rush to the counter with it, for they are the only people who can be relied upon to spend the money and create new trade.

There is only one sure way we can escape national bankruptcy - that is, to print notes and give them, not to those who now seek safety, but to the destitute, the unemployed and pensioners. An increase of 10 per cent. in all State allowances, old-age pensions, widows' pensions, unemployed benefits, public assistance, and allowances for children would be a wise beginning.

That authority supports one of the planks of the Labour party's platform. The next authority that I shall quote gives another explanation of the Labour party's remedy for our financial ills. Arthur Kitson, a British economist, states-

quote.para: BRITAIN'S REAL RULERS.

It is only within the last50 years that the sinister influence of the Bank of England has become so apparent and so dangerous to the welfare of Britain. The Bank of England is nowan international trading company controlled by 25 directors, eight of whom represent American interests and four represent German interests, with Montagu Norman the Governor-General. Britain's real ruler is neither King George V. nor Parliament; the ruler is the man or men who control the bank, who cause trade to boom or stagnate, as they wish.

debate.para: That writer was quoted several times by Senator Brennan.

talk.start.para: - No. I quoted Mr. Kitchen.
- Another authority referred to fondly by honorable senators opposite is Henry Ford, who, in the following statement, showed that he believes in high wages: -

quote.para: A manat two dollars a day has no surplus spending power, and is not a factor in the market. But a man at eight dollars has spending power and creates more. The wages of the workman are more important to the community than dividends. Our working class must become our leisure class if our immense production is to be balanced by consumption.

speech.para: The party on this side of the chamber will put forward every effort in its power, in accordance with the Standing Orders, to force the Government to increase duties ; but we shall not, inany circumstances, support those who desire to reduce them. Our objective is slowly, but surely; to make Australia a self-contained country, and to have within its shores a self-reliant people. We desire to preserve for all time the national policy of a White Australia, and adequate fiscal protection to enable that policy to be maintained.

talk.start.para: . - To employ a term used by my honorable and loquacious friend, Senator Collings, "with all respect " I suggest that we get off the soap-box and consider realities. In the first place, I propose to read some idle thoughts that I have just penned. Whenever I think of this debate, it will remind me of -

quote.para: That old man I used to know,
Whose hair was whiter than the snow;
With eyes like cinders all aglow,
Who seemed distracted with his woe;
Who rocked his body to and fro,
Who snorted like a buffalo, '
Whose words like lava used to flow,
Those winter evenings long ago,
When the. tariff was debated.

speech.para: As the hour is late, I ask leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: Assent to the following bills reported : -

quote.para: Australian Antarctic Territory Acceptance Bill.
Canned Fruits Export Control Bill 1933.

subdebateinfo.title: Darwin Unemployed - World Economic Conference - Count Out

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Sir George Pearce) proposed -

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: .- On Friday last, prior to the adjournment, I directed the attention of the Leader of the Senate to a report that the unemployed at Darwin were in such a desperate plight that they were forced in some cases to depend on the charity of Chinese residents of that town, and the right honorable gentleman stated that he would have inquiries made.

- I have sent a copy of the honorable senator's remarks to the Minister for the Interior. At present he is not in Canberra, but will return within a day or two. I shall then be able to furnish the honorable senator with his reply.
- There is one other matter which I wish to bring to the notice of the Senate. I refer to the following cabled report which appears in the Labor Daily, Sydney, of to-day's date: -

quote.para: Although the World Economic Conference is only in its second day, the proceedings are completely overshadowed by the possibility of the British default in the payment of the £19,000,000 instalment of the war debt due to America on Thursday. Disturbing reports are . current in London that the United States Government has rejected the British offer of a small - or token - payment. A semblance of authority is given to the reports by the summoning of a special meeting of the British Cabinet immediately following the dinner given to the 267 delegates to the conference last night.

speech.para: The Cabinet was called after the Prime Minister, Mr. Ramsay MacDonald, had received a despatch from the British Ambassador to Washington, Sir Ronald Lindsay. The result of the Cabinet meeting was not disclosed, but it is known that some Ministers are urging default if America adheres to its refusal to accept the token payment.

Such a course undoubtedly would receive the support of the majority of the delegates to: the conference. France has already defaulted in the payment which was due last December, and it is regarded as certain that she will againdefault in the June payment.

The main topic in London to-day was concerned with the manner in which' Mr. MacDonald took the war debts bit in his teeth at the opening of the. conference yesterday. Notwithstanding the fact that the leader of the American delegation, Mr. Hull, stated only on Friday last that the war debts could not be a matter for this, conference, Mr. MacDonald emphatically declared that " the question must be dealt with before every obstacle to general recovery has been removed, and it must be taken up without delay by the nations concerned.";

As we have in London aResident Minister without portfolio leading the Australian delegation at. the World Economic Conference, I endeavoured, this morning, to ascertain if the Government had given instructions, as to the attitude to be observed by that gentleman towards this important issue, but Senator Pearce, with his usual adroitness, gave what I regarded as a " wipe-off " to my question. I. do not in tend to take such treatment lying down. SenatorRae and I, as the representatives of the Australian Labour party of New South Wales in this chamber, were elected by the people of New South Wales, and we are in exactly the same position as is the right honorable gentleman himself, as a representative of Western Australia. To-day we have been obliged to wait approximately twelve hours for the opportunity on the motion for the adjournment of the Senate, to bring to the notice of the Government matters which we consider should be ventilated. If the, right honorable gentleman thinks that he is going to treat us always as I was treated this morning, I tell him plainly that, on every possible occasion, we shall take full advantage of the Senate Standing Orders to ventilate our grievances. We are entitled to information as to the attitude of the Government to the World Economic Conference. It is all very well for the Leader of the Senate and his colleagues to sit smiling on the front bench-

para.inline: Attention called to the state of the Senate. There being no quorum present -

speech.para: The President adjourned the Senate at 10.30 p.m.
